headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Tom Hamlin, Vice President of Investor Relations and Financ
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Tom Hamlin, Vice President of Investor Relations and Financial Planning for the safe harbor statement.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the first quarter 2016 earnings conference call for Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners. During this call, we will refer to certain schedules included in this morning's earnings releases and pages from our Earni
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the first quarter 2016 earnings conference call for Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners. During this call, we will refer to certain schedules included in this morning's earnings releases and pages from our Earnings Release Kit. Schedules in the Earnings Release Kit are intended to answer the more detailed questions pertaining to operating statistics and accounting. Investor Relations will be available after the call for any clarification of these schedules. If you've not done so, I encourage you to visit the Investor Relations page on our website, register for e-mail alerts and view our first quarter earnings document. Our website addresses are dom.com and dommidstream.com. In addition to the Earnings Release Kit, we have included a slide presentation on our website that will follow this morning's discussion. 
So now for the usual cautionary language. The earnings releases and other matters that will be discussed on the call today may contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. Please refer to our SEC filings, including our most recent annual reports on Form 10-K and our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, for a discussion of factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecasts and estimates and expectations. 
Also on this call we will discuss some measures of our companies' performance that differ from those recognized by GAAP. Reconciliation of our non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures we are able to calculate and report are contained in the Earnings Release Kit and Dominion Midstream's press release. 
Joining us on the call this morning are our CEO, Tom Farrell; our CFO, Mark McGettrick; and other members of our management team. Mark will discuss our earnings results for the first quarter and Dominion's earnings guidance for the second quarter and full year 2016. Tom will review our operating and regulatory activities and review the progress we have made on our growth plans. 
I will now turn the call over to Mark McGettrick.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Dominion Resources reported operating earnings of $0.96 per share for the first quarter of 2016, landing in the middle of our guidance range of $0.90 to $1.05 per share. Earnings drivers were as expected, with the exception of slightly milde
componenttext:
Good morning. Dominion Resources reported operating earnings of $0.96 per share for the first quarter of 2016, landing in the middle of our guidance range of $0.90 to $1.05 per share. Earnings drivers were as expected, with the exception of slightly milder weather, which was $0.03 per share lower than normal. 
GAAP earnings were $0.88 per share for the first quarter. The principal difference between GAAP and operating earnings was the charge relating to an organizational restructuring across our company, made to improve the efficiency of our reporting structure. This onetime staffing charge will support lower labor expenses in the future. The reconciliation of operating earnings to reported earnings can be found on Schedule 2 of the Earnings Release Kit.
Moving to results by operating segment. At Dominion Virginia Power, EBITDA for the first quarter was $385 million, which was in the lower half of its guidance range. Kilowatt-hour sales were mostly below expectations, primarily due to mild weather. 
Dominion Generation produced EBITDA of $610 million in the first quarter, which was in the middle of its guidance range. Lower operating expenses offset lower merchant margins and lower-than-expected kilowatt-hour sales at Virginia Power. 
First quarter EBITDA for Dominion Energy was $377 million, which was in the upper half of its guidance range. Lower operating expenses were the principal driver of the strong results. 
On a consolidated basis, interest expenses and income taxes were in line with our expectations. Overall, we are pleased with the performance of each of our operating segments.
For the first quarter 2016, Dominion Midstream Partners produced adjusted EBITDA of $24.9 million, more than double the level produced in the first quarter of last year. Distributable cash flow increased 71% to $20.3 million, which was consistent with management's expectations. Because of our strong cash position, we elected to accelerate certain planned maintenance activities at Dominion Carolina Gas that led to higher expenses in the first quarter that will not appear in future periods. 
On April 19, Dominion Midstream's Board of Directors declared a distribution of $0.2245 per unit payable on May 13. This distribution represents a 5.2% increase over last quarter's payment and is consistent with our plan to achieve 22% annual distribution growth for LP units.
In the next few days, we are planning to file with the SEC aftermarket issuance program for up to $150 million in DM common units. As a reminder, we do not need to access the markets to fund Dominion Midstream's 2016 distribution growth. However, should we decide to utilize this program, it would improve the trading liquidity of DM units, something that many of our investors have asked us about.
Moving to cash flow and treasury activities at Dominion. Funds from operations were $1.1 billion for the first 3 months of the year. Commercial paper and letters of credit outstanding at the end of the quarter was $3.1 billion. We have $5.5 billion of credit facilities, and taking into account cash and short-term investments, ended the quarter with liquidity of $2.6 billion. For statements on cash flow and liquidity, please see Pages 14 and 25 of the Earnings Release Kit.
Our public financing activities so far this year have included $750 million of senior notes at [indiscernible] and $550 million of Junior subordinated notes, which were remarketed at the Dominion Resources level. This remarketing was related to the conversion of common equity of the first tranche of mandatory convertible units issued in 2013. The remaining $550 million tranche will be remarketed later this quarter. 
In addition, we raised $750 million of common equity through a block sale in April. $500 million for that sale has been earmarked for the Questar acquisition, while the remainder was for general corporate financing needs. We have a number of debt financing planned for the remainder of the year, including issuances at Dominion, Dominion Gas Holdings and VEPCO. In addition, you should expect us to issue incremental mandatory convertible units to support the Questar transaction as we outlined on our year-end earnings call.
Looking ahead to the second quarter. Dominion's operating earnings guidance is $0.65 to $0.75 per share compared to operating earnings of $0.73 per share for the second quarter of 2015. Positive earnings drivers for the quarter compared to last year are higher revenues from our growth projects, lower capacity expense and an increase in solar-related investment tax credits. Negative drivers for the quarter are refueling outages at Millstone, a return to normal weather and share dilution. 
Dominion's operating earnings guidance for the year remains $3.60 to $4 per share. Combining 2016 actual results for the first quarter, the second quarter guidance produces year-to-date results that are $0.06 per share below last year's. Because of this shake to earnings, we wanted to highlight the earnings drivers in the second half of 2016, which will allow us to achieve our annual guidance range.
Slide 8 shows 2015's 6 months actual results of $1.72 per share and the $0.06 per share projected decline for the first half of this year, primarily due to last year's weather and this years Millstone outage. However, we have some very significant growth drivers the last 6 months of this year.
First, we expect to return to normal weather, which will allow us to pick up $0.09 to last year's results. If you recall, the weather in the fourth quarter of last year was extremely mild. We also will not have a Millstone refueling outage this fall which picks up $0.07  for us. The combined benefits of higher capacity performance revenues and a lower payment [indiscernible] generators add $0.16 per share to year-over-year results. The majority of the benefit comes from capacity performance payments based on last year's option results and will begin this summer. Also as we have said previously, we're constructing more solar projects this year, which produces an incremental $0.04 per share for the period. And finally, our restructuring changes in normal growth produced $0.02 and $0.04 per share, respectively, of higher earnings for the 6-month period. We hope this breakdown of our growth in the second half of this year provides clarity to achieving our 2016 guidance.
As to hedging, you can find our hedge positions on Page 27 of the Earnings Release Kit. As of mid-April, we are hedged 93% of our expected 2016 production at Millstone and 8% of our expected 2017 production. 
Regarding Millstone, I would like to point out that multiple New England states, including Connecticut, have been discussing longer-term RFPs in them maintaining fuel diversity environmental benefits. I do not want to speculate on the outcome of these legislative discussions, but we will be an active participant in any future solicitations. 
So let me summarize my financial review. Operating earnings were $0.96 per share for the first quarter of 2016, which was in the middle of our guidance range. Operating results for Dominion Midstream Partners were in line with management's expectations, and adjusted EBITDA was more than double the level of last year's first quarter. And finally, Dominion's operating earnings guidance for the second quarter of 2016 is $0.65 to $0.75 per share, and our operating earnings guidance through the year remains $3.60 to $4 per share. 
I will now turn the call over to Tom Farrell.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Strong operational and safety performance continued in the first quarter. Dominion was ranked #1 safety among electric utilities in the Southeast. [indiscernible] reportables for each of our business units were roughly 1/2 the level recorded
componenttext:
Good morning. Strong operational and safety performance continued in the first quarter. Dominion was ranked #1 safety among electric utilities in the Southeast. [indiscernible] reportables for each of our business units were roughly 1/2 the level recorded last year, and last year had tied an all-time company record. In fact, excluding contractor-related incidents, Dominion Generation had 0 OSHA recordables in the first quarter. 
Our nuclear fleet continues to operate very well. The net capacity factor of our 6 units was 96.2% for the first 3 months of the year. The contribution of the Warren County car stations helped our regulated power generation group achieved record net generation during the first quarter. 
North Anna Unit 2 completed a 512 consecutive day ramp when it came offline in March for its scheduled refueling. This break or break a run was a record for the unit. As Mark noted in our second quarter guidance, Millstone Unit 3 is currently in the plant refueling outage and is on plan to return to service this month. 
Now for an update on our growth plans. The 1,358-megawatt Brunswick County Power Station began commercial operations last week, completing a construction schedule that begun August of 2013 and was completed ahead of time and under budget. At the height of the construction, the station had more than 1,500 workers on site. Brunswick Power Station is anticipated at 43 employees and an annual payroll of about $7.5 million. In the first full year of the station's operation, the fuel savings had been estimated to be nearly $100 million. Those fuel savings will continue over the life of plant, and the station is expected to save consumers over $1 billion.
Development and engineering continues on our next-generation construction project with 1,588-megawatt Greensville County three-on-one combined cycle power station. On March 29, Virginia State Corporation Commission approved the CPCN and rate rider for the Greenfield project. Major contracts have been executed, including the combustion turbine supply agreement with power systems and the EPC agreement with Fluor. These are the same organizations that just completed the Brunswick County plant located about 5 miles away. We expect receiving air permit from the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality by the end of this quarter. $1.3 billion project is expected to achieve commercial operations in late 2018.
Construction on our 2 large contracted solar projects, Four Brothers and Three Cedars in Utah, continues on time and on budget. Dominion is currently overseeing the construction, and both projets are expected to be in-service during the fall of this year. 
Construction of the 80-megawatt solar facility in Virginia's Eastern shore also commenced during the first quarter and is expected to be complete in the fourth quarter of this year. The output from the Eastern shore facility is under contract with Amazon.
We are also working on a number of regulated solar projects within the state of Virginia. A hearing on the application with Virginia State Corporation Commission for the construction of 3 solar facilities within the state was held in March and the ruling is expected by July 1. If approved, these facilities totaling 56 megawatts would be in-service by late this year. 
Today, we will be filing with State Corporation Commission for a CPCN for 20 megawatts [indiscernible] facility at the site of our Remington Power Station. The output facility will be sold to the Commonwealth of Virginia and renewable energy credits will be sold to Microsoft, who will retire them. 
We have a number of electric transmission projects at various stages of regulatory approval and construction. 3 of these were completed in the first quarter, including Phase I that allowed the Pleasant View 500 KB rebuilt. We expect to place approximately $650 million of new transmission assets into service this year. 
An application for Phase I our strategic program was filed with State Corporation Commission in December. The filing, which includes a cost benefit analysis, covers 400 miles of distribution lines to be converted by August of this year at a cost of $140 million. 
Progress on our growth plan for Dominion Energy continues as well. Our Cove Point liquefaction project is approximately 64% complete and there are about 1,600 workers on site. Engineering is 99% complete, and 98% of the engineered equipment has been procured. The project continues on time and on budget for a late 2017 in-service date. 
We are continuing to work toward the commencement of construction on the Atlantic Coast Pipeline and the related Supply Header Project. We made the formal FERC filings for these projects last September. In March, after extensive consultation with stakeholders, we provided information to FERC on a route alternative to address agency and public input and to avoid more sensitive areas in the national force. Just this week, we received the supplemental notice of intent to prepare environmental impact statement as modified to include the rework. This is a very positive development, and we are pleased with our progress at FERC. We anticipate getting a FERC order to allow us to begin construction by mid-2017. Surveying pipeline engineering is nearly complete and will be furnished -- finished this year. Material [indiscernible] is now over 70% complete, and we expect to finish the construction contract this quarter. We have modified the sequence of construction with our contractors. As a result, the modest delay in permit will not delay the completion of the Atlantic Coast Pipeline or the supply header scheduled in late 2018. 
We had 1 pipeline project online in December in South Carolina, [indiscernible] 45,000 dekatherms per day, and Western Access II went online in January with 450,000 dekatherms per day capacity. 
We currently have an additional 11 pipeline growth projects underway, with $1 billion of investment to move more than 1.5 billion cubic feet per day for customers by the end of 2018. The majority of these projects are demand-driven, moving gas engines power generation for local distribution companies.
Turning to our farmout activity, we have enjoyed significant success with our Marcellus and Utica acreage farmout program, which began in 2013. Our current focus is on the portfolio of remaining Utica acreage packages and the prospect of restructuring the previously completed transactions. While many producers are pulling back near-term drilling plans, there remain significant interest in several areas throughout our farmout program. We are currently in discussions with multiple cohorts and expect to again realize significant value later this year. 
On March 31, Dominion filed its base rate case for our North Carolina service territory, seeking approval of $51.1 million increase in base rate revenues based on a 10.5% return on equity. Most of the proposed increase is expected to be offset by reductions in the fuel factor in a 2-year rider to refund excess deferred income taxes. The company has requested to implement the new rates on a temporary basis on November 1, with permanent rates being in effect on January 1. 
Finally, I want to update you on our pending merger with Questar Corporation. Hart-Scott Rodino clearance for the Questar transaction was received on February 22, and their shareholder vote is scheduled for May 12. Merger applications were filed with the Utah and Wyoming Public Service Commissions, and notice was provided to the Idaho Commission. Technical conferences were completed last week, and discovery is underway. Utah hearing scheduled for August 22, and the Wyoming hearing is scheduled for September 14. We expect to close the transaction later this year.
So to summarize, our business has delivered strong operating and exceptional safety performance in the first quarter. The Brunswick County Power Station is now complete and in-service, ahead of time and under budget. The Greensville County project has been approved, and site preparation is underway. We continue to work toward FERC approval in the Atlantic Coast Pipeline and the Supply Header Project. Construction of the Cove Point liquefaction project is on time and on budget. And we are working towards the successful close of our combination with Questar Corporation later this year. 
Thank you, and we are ready to take questions.

componenttext: Greg, this is Mark. I would say, nothing in the last 3 or 4 months. We are still [indiscernible] growth levels that we've talked about historically. componenttext: With respect to Blue Racer, Blue Racer continues along its plan. There hasn't been any changes there. It's very insignificant part of Dominion's earnings. But it's doing as anticipated and as we expected it to do this year, and it's contributing as it should to the earnings profile. With respect to Wexpro, we are going to reserve all of our comments on what happens with Questar, what our plans are for Questar until after their shareholders vote and we have a chance to further our dialogue with their management team.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are looking primarily in Virgina, both regulated. And as you may -- as we discussed in the script, couple of different sort of quasi regulated opportunities have a reason. We're looking actively there. As you commented, we are much more interested in s
componenttext: We are looking primarily in Virgina, both regulated. And as you may -- as we discussed in the script, couple of different sort of quasi regulated opportunities have a reason. We're looking actively there. As you commented, we are much more interested in solar than we are in wind. We don't -- wind is not a good asset in the territories where we do business for producing power reliably. Solar is better. And we are continuing to look at '17 and '18 so far with respect to all of our other growth projects are all on time and on budget or ahead of time and below budget, and we'll see how we go along through time to see if we're going to deploy any additional capital into renewable projects.

componenttextpreview: Jonathan, this is Mark. Obviously, we have a huge pickup on capacity performance. Often we think a lot of people probably overlooked in both '16 and '17. The '16 number on just capacity performance will be higher than it is in '17. But when you combine th
componenttext: Jonathan, this is Mark. Obviously, we have a huge pickup on capacity performance. Often we think a lot of people probably overlooked in both '16 and '17. The '16 number on just capacity performance will be higher than it is in '17. But when you combine that with no loss, it will be about the same year-over-year. And if you add on top of that the Millstone capacity in '17 over '16, we'll actually have increased our total income associated with capacity from '16 to '17 when you combine those 3 together. But we were very, very large beneficiary. And as you referenced, year-over-year, $0.16 for capacity performance, it's $0.14 in the last 6 months, and there's about $0.02 worth of incremental rolloff of notes in the last 6 months. That brings you to your $0.16 total.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to dig into the Connecticut legislation, and I guess just first perhaps try to understand the next step involved. And then we can discuss a little bit more about sort how that will exactly function. But just next steps, what should we be looking fo
componenttext: Wanted to dig into the Connecticut legislation, and I guess just first perhaps try to understand the next step involved. And then we can discuss a little bit more about sort how that will exactly function. But just next steps, what should we be looking for there?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the legislation you're referring to was adopted in the Senate and has not yet been adopted by the House. I believe Connecticut's legislature finishes their work today. But I think this is part of a dialogue that's going on all through New England an
componenttext: Well, the legislation you're referring to was adopted in the Senate and has not yet been adopted by the House. I believe Connecticut's legislature finishes their work today. But I think this is part of a dialogue that's going on all through New England and that's going to continue. It's going on in Massachusetts, it's happening in Maine, it's happening in New Hampshire, on how to deal with the carbon rules and existing carbon-free generation, of which Millstone, obviously, is the largest asset in New England. It provides half of Connecticut's power when both units are operating in these normal operations. And Connecticut has very little prospect to complying with carbon rules if Millstone were to shut down at some point. So I think the legislature political hierarchy in Connecticut is aware of that. We are following the legislation, obviously, closely. But I think it's part of an overall dialogue that will take place over the next few months in New England, generally, about how to protect these assets, of which I guess there are 2 left that are still that going to be running, Seabrook and Millstone, which is about 2x the size of Seabrook.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Steve, this is Mark. That is almost correct. The assumption though that you get a benefit for all of your generation is probably not correct. Each company would have to make a decision on how much they wanted to bid in that generation against the capacity performance and hedge their risk for any units that might not perform. So we made that analysis. And based on the generation we've bid in, covering our load requirements at 60% in the first year, that excess is the benefit I referenced.

componenttext: Two things. One, can you talk a little bit I noticed you all took about a $70 million pretax charge related to severance. Can you talk a little bit about what's going on there and what's your plans are companywide in terms of O&M, kind of what's embedded in guidance?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mark. The program that was referenced was really an effort across all the businesses and the corporate support areas to drive decision-making to a lower level, eliminate layers of management, increase management control and make the decision-makin
componenttext: This is Mark. The program that was referenced was really an effort across all the businesses and the corporate support areas to drive decision-making to a lower level, eliminate layers of management, increase management control and make the decision-making really more efficient by having those fewer layers. So that was the focus. We took a charge of about $70 million pretax. I think it's $43 million after-tax. And those labor costs will be recouped as the employees move on. And so you'll see a full year's benefit in 2017 and a partial benefit in 2016. In terms of ongoing O&M, we are targeting a flat to CPI growth on O&M going forward. It would probably be different year-by-year, and the only thing that will change on that significance will be the outage period for Millstone, where you might have 2 outages versus 1 in a given year. But I look across for you to model, flat to CPI growth on O&M going forward.

componenttext: Sales, weather-normalized for the quarter, were down about a little over 1%. We have an annual expectation of a 1% positive sales growth for the year. We still feel pretty good about that. So that's a net for the first quarter. April seemed solid and support hitting [ph] the 1% growth. And we had we actually had pretty strong growth in all sectors, but residential. I would as, always do, on sales is when you're coming and comparing to a very significant weather season, we had a very strong first quarter of 2015 on weather and in late '16 [ph] we saw the weather normalization process is not penny accurate. That's why we think 1% growth is still a good assumption for us. Also recall, 1% growth year-over-year is only equates to about $0.04, $0.05 a share for us.

componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners first quarter earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Tom Hamlin, Vice President of Investor Relations and Financial Planning, for the safe harbor statement.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to first quarter 2016 earnings conference call for Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners. During this call, we will refer to certain schedules included in this morning's earnings releases and pages from our Earnings
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to first quarter 2016 earnings conference call for Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners. During this call, we will refer to certain schedules included in this morning's earnings releases and pages from our Earnings Release Kit. Schedules in the Earnings Release Kit are intended to answer the more detailed questions pertaining to operating statistics and accounting. Investor Relations will be available after the call for any clarification of these schedules. If you've not done so, I encourage you to visit the Investor Relations page on our website, register for e-mail alerts and view our first quarter earnings documents. Our website addresses are dom.com and dommidstream.com. In addition to the Earnings Release Kit, we have included a slide presentation on our website that will follow this morning's discussion. 
So now for the usual cautionary language. The earnings releases and other matters that will be discussed on the call today may contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. Please refer to our SEC filings, including our most recent annual reports on Form 10-K and our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, for a discussion of factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecasts, estimates and expectations. 
Also, on this call, we will discuss some measures of our companies' performance that differ from those recognized by GAAP. Reconciliation of our non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures we are able to calculate and report are contained in the Earnings Release Kit and Dominion Midstream's press release. 
Joining us on the call this morning are our CEO, Tom Farrell; our CFO, Mark McGettrick; and other members of our management team. Mark will discuss our earnings results for the first quarter and Dominion's earnings guidance for the second quarter and full year 2016. Tom will review our operating and regulatory activities and review the progress we have made on our growth plans. 
I will now turn the call over to Mark McGettrick.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Dominion Resources reported operating earnings of $0.96 per share for the first quarter of 2016, landing in the middle of our guidance range of $0.90 to $1.05 per share. Earnings drivers were as expected, with the exception of slightly milde
componenttext:
Good morning. Dominion Resources reported operating earnings of $0.96 per share for the first quarter of 2016, landing in the middle of our guidance range of $0.90 to $1.05 per share. Earnings drivers were as expected, with the exception of slightly milder weather, which was $0.03 per share lower than normal. 
GAAP earnings were $0.88 per share for the first quarter. The principal difference between GAAP and operating earnings was a charge relating to an organizational restructuring across our company made to improve the efficiency of our reporting structure. This onetime staffing charge will support lower labor expenses in the future. A reconciliation of operating earnings to reported earnings can be found on Schedule 2 of the Earnings Release Kit.
Moving to results by operating segment. At Dominion Virginia Power, EBITDA for the first quarter was $385 million, which was in the lower half of its guidance range. Kilowatt-hour sales were modestly below expectations, primarily due to mild weather. 
Dominion Generation produced EBITDA of $610 million in the first quarter, which was in the middle of its guidance range. Lower operating expenses offset lower merchant margins and lower-than-expected kilowatt-hour sales at Virginia Power. 
First quarter EBITDA for Dominion Energy was $377 million, which was in the upper half of its guidance range. Lower operating expenses were the principal driver of the strong results. 
On a consolidated basis, interest expenses and income taxes were in line with our expectations. Overall, we are pleased with the performance of each of our operating segments.
For the first quarter of 2016, Dominion Midstream Partners produced adjusted EBITDA of $24.9 million, more than double the level produced in the first quarter of last year. Distributable cash flow increased 71% to $20.3 million, which was consistent with management's expectations. Because of our strong cash position, we elected to accelerate certain planned maintenance activities at Dominion Carolina Gas that led to higher expenses in the first quarter that will not appear in future periods. 
On April 19, Dominion Midstream's Board of Directors declared a distribution of $0.2245 per unit payable on May 13. This distribution represents a 5.2% increase over last quarter's payment and is consistent with our plan to achieve 22% annual distribution growth for LP units.
In the next few days, we are planning to file with the SEC for an aftermarket issuance program for up to $150 million in DM common units. As a reminder, we do not need to access the markets to fund Dominion Midstream's 2016 distribution growth. However, should we decide to utilize this program, it would improve the trading liquidity of DM units, something that many of our investors have asked us about.
Moving to cash flow and treasury activities at Dominion. Funds from operations were $1.1 billion for the first 3 months of the year. Commercial paper and letters of credit outstanding at the end of the quarter was $3.1 billion. We have $5.5 billion of credit facilities, and taking into account cash and short-term investments, ended the quarter with liquidity of $2.6 billion. For statements of cash flow and liquidity, please see Pages 14 and 25 of the Earnings Release Kit.
Our public financing activities so far this year have included $750 million of senior notes at VEPCO and $550 million of junior subordinated notes, which were remarketed at the Dominion Resources level. This remarketing was related to the conversion of common equity of the first tranche of mandatory convertible units issued in 2013. The remaining $550 million tranche will be remarketed later this quarter. 
In addition, we raised $750 million of common equity through a block sale in April. $500 million from that sale has been earmarked for the Questar acquisition, while the remainder was for general corporate financing needs. We have a number of debt financing planned for the remainder of the year, including issuances at Dominion, Dominion Gas Holdings and VEPCO. In addition, you should expect us to issue incremental mandatory convertible units to support the Questar transaction, as we outlined on our year-end earnings call.
Looking ahead to the second quarter. Dominion's operating earnings guidance is $0.65 to $0.75 per share compared to operating earnings of $0.73 per share for the second quarter of 2015. Positive earnings drivers for the quarter compared to last year are higher revenues from our growth projects, lower capacity expense and an increase in solar-related investment tax credits. Negative drivers for the quarter are refueling outage at Millstone, a return to normal weather and share dilution. 
Dominion's operating earnings guidance for the year remains: $3.60 to $4 per share. Combining 2016 actual results for the first quarter, the second quarter guidance produces year-to-date results that are $0.06 per share below last year's. Because of this shave to earnings, we wanted to highlight the earnings drivers in the second half of 2016, which will allow us to achieve our annual guidance range.
Slide 8 shows 2015's 6 months actual results of $1.72 per share and the $0.06 per share projected decline for the first half of this year, primarily due to last year's weather and this year's Millstone outage. However, we have some very significant growth drivers the last 6 months of this year.
First, we expect to return to normal weather, which will allow us to pick up $0.09 to last year's results. If you recall, the weather in the fourth quarter of last year was extremely mild. We also will not have a Millstone refueling outage this fall, which picks up $0.07  for us. The combined benefits of higher capacity performance revenues and lower payment to nonutility generators add $0.16 per share to the year-over-year results. A majority of the benefit comes from capacity performance payments based on last year's auction results and will begin this summer. Also, as we have said previously, we're constructing more solar projects this year, which produces an incremental $0.04 per share for the period. And finally, our restructuring changes and normal growth produce $0.02 and $0.04 per share, respectively, of higher earnings for the 6-month period. We hope this breakdown of our growth in the second half of this year provides clarity to achieving our 2016 guidance.
As to hedging, you can find our hedge positions on Page 27 of the Earnings Release Kit. As of mid-April, we are hedged 93% of our expected 2016 production at Millstone and 8% of our expected 2017 production. 
Regarding Millstone, I would like to point out that multiple New England states, including Connecticut, have been discussing longer-term RFPs aimed at maintaining fuel diversity and environmental benefits. I do not want to speculate on the outcome of these legislative discussions, but we will be an active participant in any future solicitations. 
So let me summarize my financial review. Operating earnings were $0.96 per share for the first quarter of 2016, which was in the middle of our guidance range. Operating results for Dominion Midstream Partners were in line with management's expectations, and adjusted EBITDA was more than double the level of last year's first quarter. And finally, Dominion's operating earnings guidance for the second quarter of 2016 is $0.65 to $0.75 per share, and our operating earnings guidance for the year remains, $3.60 to $4 per share. 
I will now turn the call over to Tom Farrell.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Strong operational and safety performance continued in the first quarter. Dominion was ranked #1 in safety among electric utilities in the Southeast. OSHA recordables for each of our business units were roughly 1/2 the level recorded last ye
componenttext:
Good morning. Strong operational and safety performance continued in the first quarter. Dominion was ranked #1 in safety among electric utilities in the Southeast. OSHA recordables for each of our business units were roughly 1/2 the level recorded last year, and last year had tied an all-time company record. In fact, excluding contractor-related incidents, Dominion Generation had 0 OSHA recordables in the first quarter. 
Our nuclear fleet continues to operate very well. The net capacity factor of our 6 units was 96.2% for the first 3 months of the year. The contribution of the Warren County power station helped our regulated power generation group achieve record net generation during the first quarter. 
North Anna Unit 2 completed a 512-consecutive-day run when it came offline in March for its scheduled refueling. This record-breaker run was a record for the unit. As Mark noted in our second quarter guidance, Millstone Unit 3 is currently in a planned refueling outage and is on plan to return to service this month. 
Now for an update on our growth plans. The 1,358-megawatt Brunswick County Power Station began commercial operations last week, completing a construction schedule that began in August of 2013 and was completed ahead of time and under budget. At the height of the construction, the station had more than 1,500 workers on site. Brunswick Power Station is anticipated to have 43 employees and an annual payroll of about $7.5 million. In the first full year of the station's operation, the fuel savings have been estimated to be nearly $100 million. Those fuel savings will continue over the life of the plant, and the station is expected to save consumers over $1 billion.
Development and engineering continues on our next-generation construction project with 1,588-megawatt Greensville County 3-on-1 combined cycle power station. On March 29, the Virginia State Corporation Commission approved the CPCN and rate rider for the Greensville project. Major contracts have been executed, including the combustion turbine supply agreement with MH Power Systems and the EPC agreement with Fluor. These are the same organizations that just completed the Brunswick County plant located about 5 miles away. We expect to receive the air permit from the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality by the end of this quarter. The $1.3 billion project is expected to achieve commercial operations in late 2018.
Construction on our 2 large contracted solar projects, Four Brothers and Three Cedars in Utah, continues on time and on budget. Dominion is currently overseeing the construction, and both projects are expected to be in service during the fall of this year. 
Construction of the 80-megawatt solar facility in Virginia's Eastern Shore also commenced during the first quarter and is expected to be complete in the fourth quarter of this year. The output from the Eastern Shore facility is under contract with Amazon.
We are also working on a number of regulated solar projects within the state of Virginia. A hearing on the application with Virginia State Corporation Commission for the construction of 3 solar facilities within the state was held in March and a ruling is expected by July 1. If approved, these facilities totaling 56 megawatts would be in service by late this year. 
Today, we will be filing with the State Corporation Commission for a CPCN for a 20-megawatt solar facility at the site of our Remington Power Station. The output from the facility will be sold to the Commonwealth of Virginia and the renewable energy credits will be sold to Microsoft, who will retire them. 
We have a number of electric transmission projects at various stages of regulatory approval and construction. Three of these were completed in the first quarter, including Phase 1 of the Loudoun-Pleasant View 500 kV rebuild. We expect to place approximately $650 million of new transmission assets into service this year. 
An application for Phase 1 our strategic underground program was filed with the State Corporation Commission in December. The filing, which includes a cost benefit analysis, covers 400 miles of distribution lines to be converted by August of this year at a cost of $140 million. 
Progress on our growth plan for Dominion Energy continues as well. Our Cove Point liquefaction project is approximately 64% complete, and there are about 1,600 workers on site. Engineering is 99% complete and 98% of the engineered equipment has been procured. The project continues on time and on budget for a late 2017 in-service date. 
We are continuing to work toward the commencement of construction on the Atlantic Coast Pipeline and the related Supply Header Project. We made the formal FERC filings for these projects last September. In March, after extensive consultation with stakeholders, we provided information to FERC on a route alternative to address agency and public input and to avoid more sensitive areas in the national force. Just this week, we received a supplemental notice of intent to prepare an environmental impact statement that is modified to include the reroute. This is a very positive development, and we are pleased with our progress at FERC. We anticipate getting a FERC order to allow us to begin construction by mid-2017. Surveying and pipeline engineering is nearly complete and will be furnished -- finished this year. Material procurement is now over 70% complete, and we expect to finish the construction contracts this quarter. We have modified the sequence of construction with our contractors. As a result, the modest delay in permitting will not delay the completion of the Atlantic Coast Pipeline or the Supply Header scheduled in late 2018. 
We had one pipeline project online in December in South Carolina, flowing 45,000 dekatherms per day, and Western Access II went online in January with 450,000 dekatherms per day capacity. 
We currently have an additional 11 pipeline growth projects underway, with $1 billion of investment to move more than 1.5 billion cubic feet per day for customers by the end of 2018. The majority of these projects are demand-driven, moving gas to end-use power generation for local distribution companies.
Turning to our farmout activity. We have enjoyed significant success with our Marcellus and Utica acreage farmout program, which began in 2013. Our current focus is on the portfolio of remaining Utica acreage packages and the prospect of restructuring our previously completed transactions. While many producers are pulling back near-term drilling plans, there remains significant interest in several areas throughout our farmout program. We are currently in discussions with multiple cohorts and expect to again realize significant value later this year. 
On March 31, Dominion filed its base rate case for our North Carolina service territory, seeking approval of a $51.1 million increase in base rate revenues based on a 10.5% return on equity. Most of the proposed increase is expected to be offset by reductions in the fuel factor and a 2-year rider to refund excess deferred income taxes. The company has requested to implement the new rates on a temporary basis on November 1, with permanent rates to be in effect on January 1. 
Finally, I want to update you on our pending merger with Questar Corporation. Hart-Scott-Rodino clearance for the Questar transaction was received on February 22, and their shareholder vote is scheduled for May 12. Merger applications were filed with the Utah and Wyoming Public Service Commissions, and notice was provided to the Idaho Commission. Technical conferences were completed last week and discovery is underway. The Utah hearing is scheduled for August 22, and the Wyoming hearing is scheduled for September 14. We expect to close the transaction later this year.
So to summarize, our business has delivered strong operating and exceptional safety performance in the first quarter. The Brunswick County Power Station is now complete and in service, ahead of time and under budget. The Greensville County project has been approved and site preparation is underway. We continue to work toward FERC approval for the Atlantic Coast Pipeline and the Supply Header Project. Construction of the Cove Point liquefaction project is on time and on budget. And we are working towards the successful close of our combination with Questar Corporation later this year. 
Thank you, and we are ready to take questions.

componenttext: Greg, this is Mark. I would say, nothing in the last 3 or 4 months. We still have the same target growth levels that we've talked about historically. But I would say that over the last 6 or 8 months, the power prices in Northeast have been weak. We think they will recover as we move through '17 -- or excuse me, move into '17. But that's probably the one variable that's out there that has gotten more negative over the last 6 or 8 months.

componenttext: It'll all be done between now and close, except for the DM equity, which -- and I think I said on my last call, that we have, as part of our bridge financing, taken out a 1-year term loan that is effective at close for up to 1 year, and it gives us flexibility to access the DM marketplace when we want, but the rest of the financing will be completed between now and close.

componenttextpreview: Well, we're looking primarily in Virginia, both regulated and, as you may -- as we discussed in the script, couple different sort of quasi-regulated opportunities that [indiscernible]. And we're looking actively there. We -- as you commented, we're much m
componenttext: Well, we're looking primarily in Virginia, both regulated and, as you may -- as we discussed in the script, couple different sort of quasi-regulated opportunities that [indiscernible]. And we're looking actively there. We -- as you commented, we're much more interested in solar than we are in wind. We don't -- wind is not a good asset in the territories where we do business for producing power reliably. Solar is better. And we are continuing to look at '17 and '18 so far, with respect to all of our other growth projects are all on time and on budget or ahead of time and below budget, and we'll see how we go along through time to see if we're going to deploy any additional capital into renewable projects.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jonathan, this is Mark. Obviously, we have a huge pickup on the capacity performance often. We think a lot of people probably have overlooked in both '16 and '17. The '16 number on just capacity performance will be higher than it is in '17. But when you c
componenttext: Jonathan, this is Mark. Obviously, we have a huge pickup on the capacity performance often. We think a lot of people probably have overlooked in both '16 and '17. The '16 number on just capacity performance will be higher than it is in '17. But when you combine that with no roll-offs, it'll be about the same year-over-year. And if you add on top of that the Millstone capacity in '17 over '16, we will actually have an increase in our total income associated with capacity from '16 to '17 when you combine those 3 together. But we were a very, very large beneficiary. And as you referenced, year-over-year, it's $0.16 for capacity performance. It's $0.14 in the last 6 months, and there's about $0.02 worth of incremental roll-off of notes in the last 6 months. That brings you to your $0.16 total.

componenttext: The -- our capacity performance specifically, the number is lower. But as I mentioned, if you combine all of our capacity resources, Millstone and no obligations, the number is actually higher.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to dig into the Connecticut legislation, and I guess, just first, perhaps try to understand the next steps involved, and then we can discuss a little bit more about sort of how that would exactly function. But just next steps, what should we be l
componenttext: I wanted to dig into the Connecticut legislation, and I guess, just first, perhaps try to understand the next steps involved, and then we can discuss a little bit more about sort of how that would exactly function. But just next steps, what should we be looking for there?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the legislation you're referring to was adopted in the Senate and has not yet been adopted by the House. I believe Connecticut's legislature finishes their work today. But I think this is part of a dialogue that's going on all through New England, a
componenttext: Well, the legislation you're referring to was adopted in the Senate and has not yet been adopted by the House. I believe Connecticut's legislature finishes their work today. But I think this is part of a dialogue that's going on all through New England, and that's going to continue. It's going on in Massachusetts, it's happening in Maine, it's happening in New Hampshire, on how to deal with the carbon rules and existing carbon-free generation, of which Millstone, obviously, is the largest asset in New England. It provides half of Connecticut's power when both units are operating and in its normal operations. And Connecticut has very little prospect of complying with carbon rules if Millstone were to shut down at some point. So I think the legislature, the political hierarchy in Connecticut is aware of that. We're following the legislation, obviously, closely. But I think it's part of an overall dialogue that will take place over the next few months in New England, generally, about how to protect these assets, of which, I guess, there are only 2 left that are still going to be running, Seabrook and Millstone, which is about 2x the size of Seabrook.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. That's helpful. And in terms of just is there a timeline in Connecticut through which we need to see either progress or -- for a resolution, i.e., is this fairly binary in terms of just deadlines for passage? Or are there opportunities to hold
componenttext: Understood. That's helpful. I'm just trying to think through what milestones we should be looking for there.

componenttext: Okay. Just to clarify, though, the -- you mentioned looking at opportunities for long-term RFPs, fuel diversity, et cetera. So as the RFPs are currently structured, can you bid Millstone into any of them? Or is it all -- I thought they only had to be new generation.

componenttext: No, it's renewables. It's quite creative and, I think, appropriate. It is carbon-free and it's base load, and they can't make their requirements without it.

componenttext: Okay. And then just one question on the -- and I apologize on the detail on this, just on the capacity performance, so to make sure I understand this. So your Virginia generation is getting capacity performance on all the generations, but in this year, you only have to buy out 60% capacity performance from your utility. But as that 60% goes to 100%, then they'll match up and there won't be a benefit. But there's a benefit from that mismatch, is that correct?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, this is Mark. That is almost correct. The assumption, though, that you get a benefit for all of your generation is probably not correct. Each company would have to make a decision on how much they wanted to bid in that generation against the capaci
componenttext: Steve, this is Mark. That is almost correct. The assumption, though, that you get a benefit for all of your generation is probably not correct. Each company would have to make a decision on how much they wanted to bid in that generation against the capacity performance and hedge their risk in -- for any units that might not perform. So we made that analysis. And based on the generation we've bid in, covering our load requirements at 60% in the first year, that excess is the benefit that I referenced.

componenttext: Okay. And just -- and then going back to the first question on your kind of growth rates and targets and all that stuff. Or are you still -- are you wanting kind of some of these pieces to come together before you reaffirm them? I just want to make sure I'm clear on what you're communicating.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two things. One, can you talk a little bit -- I noticed you all took about a $70 million pretax charge related to severance. Can you talk a little bit about what's going on there and what your plans are company-wide in terms of O&M? What -- kind of what's
componenttext: Two things. One, can you talk a little bit -- I noticed you all took about a $70 million pretax charge related to severance. Can you talk a little bit about what's going on there and what your plans are company-wide in terms of O&M? What -- kind of what's embedded in guidance?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is Mark. The program that was referenced was really an effort across all the businesses and the corporate support areas to drive decision-making to a lower level, eliminate layers of management, increase management control and make the decision
componenttext: Mike, this is Mark. The program that was referenced was really an effort across all the businesses and the corporate support areas to drive decision-making to a lower level, eliminate layers of management, increase management control and make the decision-making really more efficient by having those fewer layers. So that was the focus. We took a charge of about $70 million pretax. I think it's $43 million after tax. And those labor costs will be recouped as the employees move on. And so you'll see a full year's benefit in 2017 and a partial benefit in 2016. In terms of ongoing O&M, we're targeting a flat to CPI growth on O&M going forward. It'll probably be different year-by-year, and the only thing that would change on that of significance would be the outage period for Millstone, where you might have 2 outages versus 1 in a given year. But I look for us and for you to model flat to CPI growth on O&M going forward.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sales, weather-normalized for the quarter, were down about a little over 1%. We have an annual expectation of a 1% positive sales growth for the year. We still feel pretty good about that. So that was a net for the first quarter. April seemed solid and su
componenttext: Sales, weather-normalized for the quarter, were down about a little over 1%. We have an annual expectation of a 1% positive sales growth for the year. We still feel pretty good about that. So that was a net for the first quarter. April seemed solid and supporting the 1% growth. And we had actually pretty strong growth in all sectors but residential. I would add, as I always do, on sales is when you're coming and comparing to a very significant weather season, we had a very strong first quarter of 2015 on weather and a light '16. And so the weather-normalization process is not penny-accurate. That's why we think 1% growth is still a good assumption for us. Also, recall that 1% growth year-over-year, this only equates to about $0.04 or $0.05 a share for us.

componenttext: Paul, this is Mark. No, I don't think you should think about additional programs going forward. We took a onetime charge as we always do, it's a nonrecurring event, and disclosed that. And we showed on our breakdown on Slide 8 that we would expect to see lower operating expenses in labor due to lower staffing levels of about $0.02 this year for the last 6 months of the year. And I would expect us to see probably $0.04 or $0.05 next year, which is supportive of the growth rate that we have out there.

componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners first quarter earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Tom Hamlin, Vice President of Investor Relations and Financial Planning, for the safe harbor statement.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to first quarter 2016 earnings conference call for Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners. During this call, we will refer to certain schedules included in this morning's earnings releases and pages from our Earnings
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to first quarter 2016 earnings conference call for Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners. During this call, we will refer to certain schedules included in this morning's earnings releases and pages from our Earnings Release Kit. Schedules in the Earnings Release Kit are intended to answer the more detailed questions pertaining to operating statistics and accounting. Investor Relations will be available after the call for any clarification of these schedules. If you've not done so, I encourage you to visit the Investor Relations page on our website, register for e-mail alerts and view our first quarter earnings documents. Our website addresses are dom.com and dommidstream.com. In addition to the Earnings Release Kit, we have included a slide presentation on our website that will follow this morning's discussion. 
So now for the usual cautionary language. The earnings releases and other matters that will be discussed on the call today may contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. Please refer to our SEC filings, including our most recent annual reports on Form 10-K and our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, for a discussion of factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecasts, estimates and expectations. 
Also, on this call, we will discuss some measures of our companies' performance that differ from those recognized by GAAP. Reconciliation of our non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures we are able to calculate and report are contained in the Earnings Release Kit and Dominion Midstream's press release. 
Joining us on the call this morning are our CEO, Tom Farrell; our CFO, Mark McGettrick; and other members of our management team. Mark will discuss our earnings results for the first quarter and Dominion's earnings guidance for the second quarter and full year 2016. Tom will review our operating and regulatory activities and review the progress we have made on our growth plans. 
I will now turn the call over to Mark McGettrick.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Dominion Resources reported operating earnings of $0.96 per share for the first quarter of 2016, landing in the middle of our guidance range of $0.90 to $1.05 per share. Earnings drivers were as expected, with the exception of slightly milde
componenttext:
Good morning. Dominion Resources reported operating earnings of $0.96 per share for the first quarter of 2016, landing in the middle of our guidance range of $0.90 to $1.05 per share. Earnings drivers were as expected, with the exception of slightly milder weather, which was $0.03 per share lower than normal. 
GAAP earnings were $0.88 per share for the first quarter. The principal difference between GAAP and operating earnings was a charge relating to an organizational restructuring across our company made to improve the efficiency of our reporting structure. This onetime staffing charge will support lower labor expenses in the future. The reconciliation of operating earnings to reported earnings can be found on Schedule 2 of the Earnings Release Kit.
Moving to results by operating segment. At Dominion Virginia Power, EBITDA for the first quarter was $385 million, which was in the lower half of its guidance range. Kilowatt-hour sales were modestly below expectations, primarily due to mild weather. 
Dominion Generation produced EBITDA of $610 million in the first quarter, which was in the middle of its guidance range. Lower operating expenses offset lower merchant margins and lower-than-expected kilowatt-hour sales at Virginia Power. 
First quarter EBITDA for Dominion Energy was $377 million, which was in the upper half of its guidance range. Lower operating expenses were the principal driver of the strong results. 
On a consolidated basis, interest expenses and income taxes were in line with our expectations. Overall, we are pleased with the performance of each of our operating segments.
For the first quarter of 2016, Dominion Midstream Partners produced adjusted EBITDA of $24.9 million, more than double the level produced in the first quarter of last year. Distributable cash flow increased 71% to $20.3 million, which was consistent with management's expectations. Because of our strong cash position, we elected to accelerate certain planned maintenance activities at Dominion Carolina Gas that led to higher expenses in the first quarter that will not appear in future periods. 
On April 19, Dominion Midstream's Board of Directors declared a distribution of $0.2245 per unit payable on May 13. This distribution represents a 5.2% increase over last quarter's payment and is consistent with our plan to achieve 22% annual distribution growth for LP units.
In the next few days, we are planning to file with the SEC for an aftermarket issuance program for up to $150 million in DM common units. As a reminder, we do not need to access the markets to fund Dominion Midstream's 2016 distribution growth. However, should we decide to utilize this program, it would improve the trading liquidity of DM units, something that many of our investors have asked us about.
Moving to cash flow and treasury activities at Dominion. Funds from operations were $1.1 billion for the first 3 months of the year. Commercial paper and letters of credit outstanding at the end of the quarter were $3.1 billion. We have $5.5 billion of credit facilities, and taking into account cash and short-term investments, ended the quarter with liquidity of $2.6 billion. For statements of cash flow and liquidity, please see Pages 14 and 25 of the Earnings Release Kit.
Our public financing activities so far this year have included $750 million of senior notes at VEPCO and $550 million of junior subordinated notes, which were remarketed at the Dominion Resources level. This remarketing was related to the conversion of common equity of the first tranche of mandatory convertible units issued in 2013. The remaining $550 million tranche will be remarketed later this quarter. 
In addition, we raised $750 million of common equity through a block sale in April. $500 million from that sale has been earmarked for the Questar acquisition, while the remainder was for general corporate financing needs. We have a number of debt financing planned for the remainder of the year, including issuances at Dominion, Dominion Gas Holdings and VEPCO. In addition, you should expect us to issue incremental mandatory convertible units to support the Questar transaction, as we outlined on our year-end earnings call.
Looking ahead to the second quarter. Dominion's operating earnings guidance is $0.65 to $0.75 per share compared to operating earnings of $0.73 per share for the second quarter of 2015. Positive earnings drivers for the quarter compared to last year are higher revenues from our growth projects, lower capacity expense and an increase in solar-related investment tax credits. Negative drivers for the quarter are refueling outage at Millstone, a return to normal weather and share dilution. 
Dominion's operating earnings guidance for the year remains: $3.60 to $4 per share. Combining 2016 actual results for the first quarter, the second quarter guidance produces year-to-date results that are $0.06 per share below last year's. Because of this shave to earnings, we wanted to highlight the earnings drivers in the second half of 2016, which will allow us to achieve our annual guidance range.
Slide 8 shows 2015's 6 months actual results of $1.72 per share and the $0.06 per share projected decline for the first half of this year, primarily due to last year's weather and this year's Millstone outage. However, we have some very significant growth drivers the last 6 months of this year.
First, we expect to return to normal weather, which will allow us to pick up $0.09 to last year's results. If you recall, the weather in the fourth quarter of last year was extremely mild. We also will not have a Millstone refueling outage this fall, which picks up $0.07  for us. The combined benefits of higher capacity performance revenues and lower payment to nonutility generators add $0.16 per share to the year-over-year results. A majority of the benefit comes from capacity performance payments based on last year's auction results and will begin this summer. Also, as we have said previously, we're constructing more solar projects this year, which produces an incremental $0.04 per share for the period. And finally, our restructuring changes and normal growth produce $0.02 and $0.04 per share, respectively, of higher earnings for the 6-month period. We hope this breakdown of our growth in the second half of this year provides clarity to achieving our 2016 guidance.
As to hedging, you can find our hedge positions on Page 27 of the Earnings Release Kit. As of mid-April, we are hedged 93% of our expected 2016 production at Millstone and 8% of our expected 2017 production. 
Regarding Millstone, I would like to point out that multiple New England states, including Connecticut, have been discussing longer-term RFPs aimed at maintaining fuel diversity and environmental benefits. I do not want to speculate on the outcome of these legislative discussions, but we will be an active participant in any future solicitations. 
So let me summarize my financial review. Operating earnings were $0.96 per share for the first quarter of 2016, which was in the middle of our guidance range. Operating results for Dominion Midstream Partners were in line with management's expectations, and adjusted EBITDA was more than double the level of last year's first quarter. And finally, Dominion's operating earnings guidance for the second quarter of 2016 is $0.65 to $0.75 per share, and our operating earnings guidance for the year remains, $3.60 to $4 per share. 
I will now turn the call over to Tom Farrell.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Strong operational and safety performance continued in the first quarter. Dominion was ranked #1 in safety among electric utilities in the Southeast. OSHA recordables for each of our business units were roughly 1/2 the level recorded last ye
componenttext:
Good morning. Strong operational and safety performance continued in the first quarter. Dominion was ranked #1 in safety among electric utilities in the Southeast. OSHA recordables for each of our business units were roughly 1/2 the level recorded last year, and last year had tied an all-time company record. In fact, excluding contractor-related incidents, Dominion Generation had 0 OSHA recordables in the first quarter. 
Our nuclear fleet continues to operate very well. The net capacity factor of our 6 units was 96.2% for the first 3 months of the year. The contribution of the Warren County power station helped our regulated power generation group achieve record net generation during the first quarter. 
North Anna Unit 2 completed a 512-consecutive-day run when it came offline in March for its scheduled refueling. This record-breaker run was a record for the unit. As Mark noted in our second quarter guidance, Millstone Unit 3 is currently in a planned refueling outage and is on plan to return to service this month. 
Now for an update on our growth plans. The 1,358-megawatt Brunswick County Power Station began commercial operations last week, completing a construction schedule that began in August of 2013 and was completed ahead of time and under budget. At the height of the construction, the station had more than 1,500 workers on site. Brunswick Power Station is anticipated to have 43 employees and an annual payroll of about $7.5 million. In the first full year of the station's operation, the fuel savings have been estimated to be nearly $100 million. Those fuel savings will continue over the life of the plant, and the station is expected to save consumers over $1 billion.
Development and engineering continues on our next-generation construction project with 1,588-megawatt Greensville County 3-on-1 combined cycle power station. On March 29, the Virginia State Corporation Commission approved the CPCN and rate rider for the Greensville project. Major contracts have been executed, including the combustion turbine supply agreement with MH Power Systems and the EPC agreement with Fluor. These are the same organizations that just completed the Brunswick County plant located about 5 miles away. We expect to receive the air permit from the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality by the end of this quarter. The $1.3 billion project is expected to achieve commercial operations in late 2018.
Construction on our 2 large contracted solar projects, Four Brothers and Three Cedars in Utah, continues on time and on budget. Dominion is currently overseeing the construction, and both projects are expected to be in service during the fall of this year. 
Construction of the 80-megawatt solar facility in Virginia's Eastern Shore also commenced during the first quarter and is expected to be complete in the fourth quarter of this year. The output from the Eastern Shore facility is under contract with Amazon.
We are also working on a number of regulated solar projects within the state of Virginia. A hearing on the application with Virginia State Corporation Commission for the construction of 3 solar facilities within the state was held in March and a ruling is expected by July 1. If approved, these facilities totaling 56 megawatts would be in service by late this year. 
Today, we will be filing with the State Corporation Commission for a CPCN for a 20-megawatt solar facility at the site of our Remington Power Station. The output from the facility will be sold to the Commonwealth of Virginia and the renewable energy credits will be sold to Microsoft, who will retire them. 
We have a number of electric transmission projects at various stages of regulatory approval and construction. Three of these were completed in the first quarter, including Phase 1 of the Loudoun-Pleasant View 500 kV rebuild. We expect to place approximately $650 million of new transmission assets into service this year. 
An application for Phase 1 of our strategic underground program was filed with the State Corporation Commission in December. The filing, which includes a cost benefit analysis, covers 400 miles of distribution lines to be converted by August of this year at a cost of $140 million. 
Progress on our growth plan for Dominion Energy continues as well. Our Cove Point liquefaction project is approximately 64% complete, and there are about 1,600 workers on site. Engineering is 99% complete and 98% of the engineered equipment has been procured. The project continues on time and on budget for a late 2017 in-service date. 
We are continuing to work toward the commencement of construction on the Atlantic Coast Pipeline and the related Supply Header Project. We made the formal FERC filings for these projects last September. In March, after extensive consultation with stakeholders, we provided information to FERC on a route alternative to address agency and public input and to avoid more sensitive areas in the national force. Just this week, we received a supplemental notice of intent to prepare an environmental impact statement that is modified to include the reroute. This is a very positive development, and we are pleased with our progress at FERC. We anticipate getting a FERC order to allow us to begin construction by mid-2017. Surveying and pipeline engineering is nearly complete and will be furnished -- finished this year. Material procurement is now over 70% complete, and we expect to finish the construction contracts this quarter. We have modified the sequence of construction with our contractors. As a result, the modest delay in permitting will not delay the completion of the Atlantic Coast Pipeline or the Supply Header scheduled in late 2018. 
We had one pipeline project online in December in South Carolina, flowing 45,000 dekatherms per day, and Western Access II went online in January with 450,000 dekatherms per day capacity. 
We currently have an additional 11 pipeline growth projects underway, with $1 billion of investment to move more than 1.5 billion cubic feet per day for customers by the end of 2018. The majority of these projects are demand-driven, moving gas to end-use power generation for local distribution companies.
Turning to our farmout activity. We have enjoyed significant success with our Marcellus and Utica acreage farmout program, which began in 2013. Our current focus is on the portfolio of remaining Utica acreage packages and the prospect of restructuring a previously completed transaction. While many producers are pulling back near-term drilling plans, there remains significant interest in several areas throughout our farmout program. We are currently in discussions with multiple cohorts and expect to again realize significant value later this year. 
On March 31, Dominion filed its base rate case for our North Carolina service territory, seeking approval of a $51.1 million increase in base rate revenues based on a 10.5% return on equity. Most of the proposed increase is expected to be offset by reductions in the fuel factor in a 2-year rider to refund excess deferred income taxes. The company has requested to implement the new rates on a temporary basis on November 1, with permanent rates to be in effect on January 1. 
Finally, I want to update you on our pending merger with Questar Corporation. Hart-Scott-Rodino clearance for the Questar transaction was received on February 22, and their shareholder vote is scheduled for May 12. Merger applications were filed with the Utah and Wyoming Public Service Commissions, and notice was provided to the Idaho Commission. Technical conferences were completed last week and discovery is underway. The Utah hearing is scheduled for August 22, and the Wyoming hearing is scheduled for September 14. We expect to close the transaction later this year.
So to summarize, our business has delivered strong operating and exceptional safety performance in the first quarter. The Brunswick County Power Station is now complete and in service, ahead of time and under budget. The Greensville County project has been approved's and site preparation is underway. We continue to work toward FERC approval for the Atlantic Coast Pipeline and the Supply Header Project. Construction of the Cove Point liquefaction project is on time and on budget. And we are working towards the successful close of our combination with Questar Corporation later this year. 
Thank you, and we are ready to take questions.

componenttext: Greg, this is Mark. I would say nothing in the last 3 or 4 months. We still have the same target growth levels that we've talked about historically. But I would say that over the last 6 or 8 months, the power prices in the Northeast have been weak. We think they will recover as we move through '17 -- or excuse me, move into '17. But that's probably the one variable that's out there that has gotten more negative over the last 6 or 8 months.

componenttext: It'll all be done between now and close, except for the DM equity, which -- and I think I said on my last call, that we have, as part of our bridge financing, taken out a 1-year term loan that is effective at close for up to 1 year, and it gives us flexibility to access the DM marketplace when we want, but the rest of the financing will be completed between now and close.

componenttext: Julien, with respect to Blue Racer, Blue Racer continues along its plan. There haven't been any changes there. It's a very insignificant part of Dominion's earnings. But it's there -- it's doing as anticipated and as we expected it to do this year, and it's contributing as it should to the earnings profile. With respect to Wexpro, we're going to reserve all of our comments on what happens with Questar, what our plans are for Questar until after their shareholders vote and we have a chance to further our dialogue with their management team.
