componenttext: Got it. And then, unrelated, if you can talk about the renewables opportunity. Obviously, you guys are trying to scale that in Virginia, but given the extensions, how are you thinking about deploying further -- especially solar assets in '17 and '18 as you think about any potential pressures on your earnings growth because of commodity, et cetera?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're looking primarily in Virginia, both regulated and, as you may -- as we discussed in the script, couple different sort of quasi-regulated opportunities that were risen. And we're looking actively there. We -- as you commented, we're much more i
componenttext: Well, we're looking primarily in Virginia, both regulated and, as you may -- as we discussed in the script, couple different sort of quasi-regulated opportunities that were risen. And we're looking actively there. We -- as you commented, we're much more interested in solar than we are in wind. We don't -- wind is not a good asset in the territories where we do business for producing power reliably. Solar is better. And we are continuing to look at '17 and '18 so far, with respect to all of our other growth projects are all on time and on budget or ahead of time and below budget, and we'll see how we go along through time to see if we're going to deploy any additional capital into renewable projects.

componenttextpreview: Jonathan, this is Mark. Obviously, we had a huge pickup on the capacity performance often, which we think a lot of people probably overlooked in both '16 and '17. The '16 number on just capacity performance will be higher than it is in '17. But when you c
componenttext: Jonathan, this is Mark. Obviously, we had a huge pickup on the capacity performance often, which we think a lot of people probably overlooked in both '16 and '17. The '16 number on just capacity performance will be higher than it is in '17. But when you combine that with no roll-offs, it'll be about the same year-over-year. And if you add on top of that the Millstone capacity in '17 over '16, we will actually have an increase in our total income associated with capacity from '16 to '17 when you combine those 3 together. But we were a very, very large beneficiary. And as you referenced, year-over-year, it's $0.16 for capacity performance. It's $0.14 in the last 6 months, and there's about $0.02 worth of incremental roll-off of notes in the last 6 months. That brings you to your $0.16 total.

componenttext: Remember how this capacity auction worked in PJM. You had to cover 60% of your load in the first year, and I think it was 70% of your load. So the opportunity on capacity performance will get smaller as you have to cover more of your load moving forward. So '16 is the biggest year for that one single item, and it starts to whittle down from there. But we're quite pleased with the result for us.

componenttext: Well, we did one last year, Greg, and it could be a variety of different examples. Some of the cases, they have -- when we did the farmouts, they were agreed to drilling schedules. And if they -- for example, if someone wanted to modify the drilling schedule, they would have to compensate us for that. So that's the kind of activity we're looking at. But the primary activities in the traditional farmout, we still have a lot of Utica acreage and we have a tremendous amount of interest in it.

componenttext: I wanted to dig into the Connecticut legislation, and I guess, just first, perhaps try to understand the next steps involved, and then we can discuss a little bit more about sort of how that would exactly function. But just next steps, what should we be looking for there?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the legislation you're referring to was adopted in the Senate and has not yet been adopted by the House. I believe Connecticut's legislature finishes their work today. But I think this is part of a dialogue that's going on all through New England, a
componenttext: Well, the legislation you're referring to was adopted in the Senate and has not yet been adopted by the House. I believe Connecticut's legislature finishes their work today. But I think this is part of a dialogue that's going on all through New England, and it's going to continue. It's going on in Massachusetts, it's happening in Maine, it's happening in New Hampshire, on how to deal with the carbon rules and existing carbon-free generation, of which Millstone, obviously, is the largest asset in New England. It provides half of Connecticut's power when both units are operating in its normal operations. And Connecticut has very little prospect of complying with carbon rules if Millstone were to shut down at some point. So I think the legislature, the political hierarchy in Connecticut is aware of that. We're following the legislation, obviously, closely. But I think it's part of an overall dialogue that will take place over the next few months in New England, generally, about how to protect these assets, of which, I guess, there are only 2 left that are still going to be running, Seabrook and Millstone, which is about 2x the size of Seabrook.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Understood. That's helpful. I'm just trying to think through what milestones we should be looking for there.

componenttext: Okay. And then just one question on the -- and I apologize on the detail on this, just on the capacity performance, just to make sure I understand this. So your Virginia generation is getting capacity performance on all the generations, but in this year, you only have to buy out 60% capacity performance from your utility. But as that 60% goes to 100%, then they'll match up and there won't be a benefit. But there's a benefit from that mismatch, is that correct?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, this is Mark. That is almost correct. The assumption, though, that you get a benefit for all of your generation is probably not correct. Each company would have to make a decision on how much they wanted to bid in that generation against the capaci
componenttext: Steve, this is Mark. That is almost correct. The assumption, though, that you get a benefit for all of your generation is probably not correct. Each company would have to make a decision on how much they wanted to bid in that generation against the capacity performance and hedge their risk in -- for any units that might not perform. So we made that analysis. And based on the generation we've bid in, covering our load requirements at 60% in the first year, that excess is the benefit that I referenced.

componenttextpreview: Two things. One, can you talk a little bit -- I noticed you all took about a $70 million pretax charge related to severance. Can you talk a little bit about what's going on there and what your plans are company-wide in terms of O&M? What -- kind of what's
componenttext: Two things. One, can you talk a little bit -- I noticed you all took about a $70 million pretax charge related to severance. Can you talk a little bit about what's going on there and what your plans are company-wide in terms of O&M? What -- kind of what's embedded in guidance?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is Mark. The program that was referenced was really an effort across all the businesses and the corporate support areas to drive decision-making to a lower level, eliminate layers of management, increase management control and make the decision
componenttext: Mike, this is Mark. The program that was referenced was really an effort across all the businesses and the corporate support areas to drive decision-making to a lower level, eliminate layers of management, increase management control and make the decision-making really more efficient by having those fewer layers. So that was the focus. We took a charge of about $70 million pretax. I think it's $43 million after tax. And those labor costs will be recouped as the employees move on. And so you'll see a full year's benefit in 2017 and a partial benefit in 2016. In terms of ongoing O&M, we're targeting a flat to CPI growth on O&M going forward. It'll probably be different year-by-year, and the only thing that would change on that of significance would be the outage period for Millstone, where you might have 2 outages versus 1 in a given year. But I look for us and for you to model flat to CPI growth on O&M going forward.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sales, weather-normalized for the quarter, were down about a little over 1%. We have an annual expectation of a 1% positive sales growth for the year. We still feel pretty good about that. So that was a net for the first quarter. April seemed solid in sup
componenttext: Sales, weather-normalized for the quarter, were down about a little over 1%. We have an annual expectation of a 1% positive sales growth for the year. We still feel pretty good about that. So that was a net for the first quarter. April seemed solid in supporting the 1% growth. And we had actually pretty strong growth in all sectors but residential. I would add, as I always do on sales, is when you're coming and comparing to a very significant weather season, we had a very strong first quarter of 2015 on weather and a light '16. And so the weather-normalization process is not penny-accurate. That's why we think 1% growth is still a good assumption for us. Also, recall that 1% growth year-over-year, this only equates to about $0.04 or $0.05 a share for us.

componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Tom Hamlin, Vice President of Investor Relations and Financial Planning, for the safe harbor statement.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call for Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners.During this call, we will refer to certain schedules included in this morning's earnings releases and pages from our Ear
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call for Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners.
During this call, we will refer to certain schedules included in this morning's earnings releases and pages from our Earnings Release Kit. Schedules in the Earnings Release Kit are intended to answer the more detailed questions pertaining to operating statistics and accounting.
Investor Relations will be available after the call for any clarification of these schedules. If you've not done so, I encourage you to visit the Investor Relations page on our website, register for e-mail alerts and view our second quarter earnings documents.
Our website addresses are dom.com and dommidstream.com. In addition to the Earnings Release Kit, we have included a slide presentation on our website that will follow this morning's discussion.
And now for the usual cautionary language. The earnings releases and other matters that will be discussed on the call today may contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties.
Please refer to our SEC filings, including our most recent annual reports on Form 10-K and our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, for a discussion of factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecasts, estimates and expectations.
Also on this call, we will discuss some measures of our companies' performance that differ from those recognized by GAAP.
Reconciliation of our non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures we are able to calculate and report are contained in the Earnings Release Kit and Dominion Midstream's press release.
Joining us on the call this morning are our CEO, Tom Farrell; our CFO, Mark McGettrick; and other members of our management team. Mark will discuss our earnings results for the second quarter and Dominion's earnings guidance for the third quarter and full year 2016. Tom will review our operating and regulatory activity and review the progress we've made on our growth plans. 
I will now turn the call over to Mark McGettrick.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Dominion Resources reported operating earnings of $0.71 per share for the second quarter of 2016, finishing in the upper half of our guidance range of $0.65 to $0.75 per share. Operating earnings would have been at the top of our guidance ra
componenttext:
Good morning. Dominion Resources reported operating earnings of $0.71 per share for the second quarter of 2016, finishing in the upper half of our guidance range of $0.65 to $0.75 per share. Operating earnings would have been at the top of our guidance range were it not for the impact of milder-than-normal weather and higher storm restoration costs. 
GAAP earnings were $0.73 per share for the second quarter. The principal difference between GAAP and operating earnings was a gain related to our investments in nuclear decommissioning trust funds. A reconciliation of operating earnings to reported earnings can be found on Schedule 2 of the Earnings Release Kit. 
Moving to results by operating segment. At Dominion Virginia Power, EBITDA for the second quarter was $363 million, which was in the lower half of its guidance range. Negative drivers for the quarter were higher major storm restoration costs and lower kilowatt-hour sales, primarily due to mild weather. These were partially offset by growth in rate base and lower operating expenses. 
Dominion Generation produced EBITDA of $509 million in the second quarter, which was in the upper half of its guidance range. Lower operating expenses and higher rider revenues offset lower-than-expected kilowatt-hour sales at Virginia Power. 
Second quarter EBITDA for Dominion Energy was $336 million, which was near the top of its guidance range. Lower operating expenses were the principal driver of the strong results. 
On a consolidated basis, interest expenses and income taxes were in line with our expectations. Overall, we were pleased with the performance of each of our operating segments. 
For the second quarter of 2016, Dominion Midstream Partners produced adjusted EBITDA of $27.2 million, 37% higher than the level produced in the second quarter of last year. Distributable cash flow increased 31% to $23.8 million, which was consistent with management's expectations. 
On July 22, Dominion Midstream's Board of Directors declared a distribution of $0.2355 per unit payable on August 15. This distribution represents a 5% increase over last quarter's payment and is consistent with our plan to achieve 22% annual distribution growth for LP units. 
Now moving to the cash flow and treasury activities at Dominion. Funds from operations were $2 billion for the first 6 months of the year. We have $5.5 billion of credit facilities, and taking into account restricted cash and short-term investments, we ended the quarter with liquidity of $2.8 billion. 
For statements of cash flow and liquidity, please see Pages 14 and 25 of the Earnings Release Kit. 
During the second quarter, we completed a number of financing transactions to support our growth plan and cover the acquisition of Questar. Slide 6 highlights our recent financing activities. We have a few debt financings planned for the remainder of the year, including issuances at Dominion and VEPCO. In addition, you should expect us to issue incremental mandatory convertible units to support the Questar transaction. 
Looking ahead to the third quarter, Dominion's operating earnings guidance is $0.95 to $1.10 per share. The midpoint of that range is unchanged from the operating earnings of $1.03 per share for the third quarter of 2015. Positive earnings drivers for the quarter compared to last year are higher revenues from our growth projects and lower capacity expenses for Virginia Power. Negative drivers for the quarter compared to last year include the absence of a farm-out agreement and a higher share count. Dominion's operating earnings guidance for the year remains $3.60 to $4 per share. 
Slide 8 is an update of a slide we showed last quarter, which highlights the earnings drivers in the fourth quarter of 2016, which will allow us to achieve our annual guidance range. The chart begins as our actual operating earnings for the first half of 2016 plus the midpoint of our guidance for the third quarter. The middle of the chart details the positive and negative drivers to this year's fourth quarter relative to the prior year. 
We show about $0.07 per share of year-over-year negative drivers, principally financing costs and DD&A. We did highlight about $0.47 per share of year-over-year positive drivers in the fourth quarter, including normal weather, lower capacity expenses and the absence of a Millstone outage. 
As to hedging, you can find our hedge positions on Page 27 of the Earnings Release Kit. As of mid-July, we have hedged 95% of our expected 2016 production at Millstone and 8% of our expected 2017 production. 
So let me summarize my financial review. Operating earnings were $0.71 per share for the second quarter of 2016, which was in the upper half of our guidance range. Operating results for Dominion Midstream Partners were in line with management's expectations. And finally, Dominion's operating earnings guidance for the third quarter is $0.95 to $1.10 per share, and full year earnings guidance remains $3.60 to $4 per share. 
I will now turn the call over to Tom Farrell.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Strong operational and safety performance continued in the second quarter. All of our business units are on track to meet or exceed their safety goals for the year. Our nuclear fleet continues to operate well. The net capacity factor of ou
componenttext:
Good morning. Strong operational and safety performance continued in the second quarter. All of our business units are on track to meet or exceed their safety goals for the year. 
Our nuclear fleet continues to operate well. The net capacity factor of our 6 units was 92% for the first 6 months of the year. The contribution of the Brunswick County power station helped our regulated power generation group achieve record net generation. 
Our Nuclear business unit completed 2 successful refueling outages in the second quarter. The outage at Millstone Unit 3 was completed in 34 days, and the refueling of Unit 2 at North Anna was completed in 35 days. 
Now for an update on our growth plans. The 1,358-megawatt Brunswick County power station began commercial operations in April, completing a construction schedule that began in August 2013, and was completed ahead of time and under budget. 
We have begun construction of the 1,588-megawatt Greensville County combined cycle power station. The air permit for the project was issued by the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality on June 17, and a full notice to proceed was given to Fluor that same day. 
The $1.3 billion project is expected to achieve commercial operations in late 2018. Construction on our 2 large contracted solar projects, Four Brothers and Three Cedars in Utah, continues on time and on budget. All sites are mechanically complete with grid synchronization underway. Both projects are expected to be in service this quarter. 
Virginia Governor Terry McAuliffe affirmed his intention for the Commonwealth to move forward on implementing the power plant in signing Executive Order 57 in June 28. The order set up an executive branch working group to identify executive actions that could be taken to reduce carbon emissions from the electric utility sector. Continued focus on carbon reduction combined with demand for low carbon options by our customers may require significant additional low or no carbon power generation investment in Virginia. We have a number solar projects under development in the state today and continue to see demand for renewables from our customers, including data centers and military installations. 
Construction of the 80-megawatt solar facility in Virginia's Eastern Shore is underway and is expected be completed in the fourth quarter. The output from the Eastern Shore facility is under contract with our data center customer, Amazon. 
On June 30, Virginia State Corporation Commission approved 3 solar projects in Virginia. These facilities, totaling 56 megawatts, is also expected to be in service by late this year. We have filed with the state Corporation Commission for approval of an additional 20-megawatt solar facility at the site of our Remington power station to be in service next year. The output from this facility will be sold to the Commonwealth of Virginia, and the renewable energy credits will be sold to Microsoft. 
In July, we signed a lease with the Department of the Navy to develop an 18-megawatt solar facility at the Oceana Naval Air Station in Virginia Beach, and Monday filed for approval with the state Corporation Commission. The output of Oceana is under long-term contract with the Commonwealth of Virginia. If approved by the state Corporation Commission, this facility is expected to be in service by late next year. 
We have a number of electric transmission projects at various stages of regulatory approval and construction. $360 million worth of these facilities were completed in the second quarter, including our new systems operations center. We expect to place over $680 million of new transmission assets into service this year. 
An application for Phase 1 of our strategic distribution underground program was filed with the state Corporation Commission, filing which includes a cost-benefit analysis, covers 400 miles of distribution lines to be converted this year at a cost of $140 million, and SEC is expected to rule on the filing next month. 
Progress on our growth plan for Dominion Energy continues as well. Our Cove Point Liquefaction project is now 67% complete with over 1,800 construction workers offsite. Our engineering, procurement and structured contractor, IHIQ [ph], has installed well over half of 21,500 tons of structural steel required, and the piping installation is proceeding on plan. We are on schedule to have all major equipment installation on foundations by end of the year. 
Our operations staffing plan is also on schedule. The formal classroom training began in the second quarter and will continue throughout the facility commissioning. Project continues on time and on budget for a late 2017 in-service date. 
We're continuing to work toward the commencement of construction on the Atlantic Coast Pipeline and the related Supply Header projects. We made the formal FERC filings for these projects last September. In April, after submitting details of a reroute that avoids sensitive areas within the United States for service lands, we received a supplemental notice of intent to prepare an environmental impact statement. We have continued to respond to data requests, and we were quite pleased with our progress at FERC. We anticipate receiving a scheduling order very soon followed by a permit, which allows to begin construction by mid-2017. 
Surveying and pipeline engineering is nearly complete and will be finished this year. Materials procurement is now over 80% complete, and we are finalizing our detailed construction plan. We expect completion of the Atlantic Coast Pipeline Supply Header in late 2018. 
The St. Charles market access project delivering 132,000 dekatherms per day to a CPV power plant in Maryland was completed June 1, on time and on budget. We currently have 4 projects under construction for an additional 600,000 dekatherms per day to come online later this year. 
In total, we have 10 pipeline growth projects underway in addition to the Atlantic Coast Pipeline Supply Header, with $1 billion of investment to move more than 1.5 billion cubic feet per day for customers by the end of 2018. The minority -- the majority of the projects are demand driven, moving gas to end-use power generation or local distribution companies. 
Turning to our farmout activity. We have enjoyed significant success with our Marcellus and Utica acreage farmout program, which began in 2013. Our current focus is on the portfolio of remaining Utica acreage packages and the prospect of restructuring a previously completed transactions. While many producers pulled back near-term drilling plans, there remains significant interest in several areas throughout our farmout program. 
During the second quarter, we restructured a previous agreement covering 79,000 acres of Marcellus shale development rights. As part of the restructuring, parties have agreed to convey immediately a portion of the acreage to facilitate its development, resulting in the recognition of $36 million of revenue. We are currently in discussions with multiple parties and expect to realize additional value later this year. 
On March 31, Dominion filed its base rate case for our North Carolina service territory seeking approval of a $51.1 million increase to base rate revenues based on a 10.5 return on equity. The North Carolina Commission issued a procedural order in May that calls for hearings in October. We have requested to implement the proposed rates subject to refund November 1 with permanent rates becoming effective January 1 of next year. 
Finally, I want to update you on our pending merger with Questar Corporation. Questar's shareholders approved the transaction in May. Merger applications were filed with the Utah and Wyoming Public Service Commissions, and notice was provided to the Idaho Commission. 
Technical conferences were completed last quarter, and discovery is almost complete. On August 1, we filed a settlement stipulation with the Wyoming Commission related to the merger. We will file supporting testimony on August 11, and we'll present the settlement to the Wyoming Commission on September 14. 
On July 28, we filed a final testimony with the Utah Commission. The hearing before that, the Commission has scheduled for August 22. We expect to close the transaction by year-end. 
So to summarize, our business has delivered strong operating and safety performance in the second quarter with Brunswick County power stations now complete and in service, ahead of time and under budget. The Greensville County project has been approved, and construction is underway. The construction of the Cove Point Liquefaction project is on time and on budget. We continue to work toward FERC approval for the Atlantic Coast Pipeline and the Supply Header project, and we are working toward a successful close of our combination with Questar Corporation later this year. 
Thank you, and we are ready to take your questions.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So perhaps just a follow-up here. On 2017, can you elaborate a little bit on where you stand? Obviously, a little bit preempting guidance here later this year, but where do you stand relative to Millstone and hedging and provide a little bit more thought
componenttext: So perhaps just a follow-up here. On 2017, can you elaborate a little bit on where you stand? Obviously, a little bit preempting guidance here later this year, but where do you stand relative to Millstone and hedging and provide a little bit more thought on timing for hedging, given where the commodity markets have been this year.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julien, this is Mark. As you can see from our hedge schedules, we didn't hedge anything in the second quarter of this year, and we actually don't expect to hedge much in the third quarter this year, either. Our view is that the oversupply that occurred be
componenttext: Julien, this is Mark. As you can see from our hedge schedules, we didn't hedge anything in the second quarter of this year, and we actually don't expect to hedge much in the third quarter this year, either. Our view is that the oversupply that occurred because a very mild winter and a very high production cycle over the last year or so is normalizing, and we think with a warm summer this year going into the fall that storage will be full early, and we will see more bullish price signals in the Northeast as we go into the winter period. That being said, we've referenced a number of times that as we go into a calendar year and certainly by the, call it, the end of January, early February, we would expect Millstone to be hedged between 80% and 90%, which it always has been. But our hedge view is that we are going to wait till later this year to place more hedges on that facility.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, and therefore, holding off on providing any more formal commentary on '17, right?
componenttext: Got it, and therefore, holding off on providing any more formal commentary on '17, right?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right. I mean, we always give guidance for the calendar year typically in January, and that's still our view for 2017. But there's no question that the Millstone revenue streams driven by power prices are big driver to '17, one way or the other, an
componenttext: That's right. I mean, we always give guidance for the calendar year typically in January, and that's still our view for 2017. But there's no question that the Millstone revenue streams driven by power prices are big driver to '17, one way or the other, and we want to get a very clear view on that before we give our annual guidance for 2017.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And also to clarify, I know you're trying to time things for hedges on '17. Just on going forward, what are your expectations for hedging policy? Anything beyond kind of year 1 hedge in January?
componenttext: And also to clarify, I know you're trying to time things for hedges on '17. Just on going forward, what are your expectations for hedging policy? Anything beyond kind of year 1 hedge in January?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we typically, over the years, have averaged hedges over a 3-year period pretty routinely, but we changed that about a year or so ago when we saw this very steep, very quick decline in power prices, which we do not think is sustainable. Obviously, to
componenttext: Well, we typically, over the years, have averaged hedges over a 3-year period pretty routinely, but we changed that about a year or so ago when we saw this very steep, very quick decline in power prices, which we do not think is sustainable. Obviously, too, Julien, you watch us closely that there's a lot of legislative activity occurring in the Northeast that could well impact nuclear and power prices in general. We want to see we can get a little more clarity on some of those activities. So we will be market sensitive to this. But unless the forward curves move, we're not going to be in a hurry to hedge, by the way, beyond 2017.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, and then just following up on separate subject here. On ITCs, can you clarify a little bit, where do you stand on 2017 relative to plan? I know you guys talked about $0.10 to $0.15. You've announced a few projects thus far, I think for next year i
componenttext: Got it, and then just following up on separate subject here. On ITCs, can you clarify a little bit, where do you stand on 2017 relative to plan? I know you guys talked about $0.10 to $0.15. You've announced a few projects thus far, I think for next year in VEPCO. Can you also clarify which projects qualify for the ITCs and which ones don't under your -- under VEPCO? And then maybe just a further detail, what's the total for '16 just to get it out there between VEPCO and [indiscernible].

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'll take any questions here, Julien. I'll be glad to answer all. Let's start with this year's ITCs based on the project that have been announced, and we talked about this on previous calls. The projects in Utah, which are very large projects, will
componenttext: Okay. I'll take any questions here, Julien. I'll be glad to answer all. Let's start with this year's ITCs based on the project that have been announced, and we talked about this on previous calls. The projects in Utah, which are very large projects, will produce between $0.30 and $0.35 of earnings from ITCs, and that range is really based on whatever the actual capital costs might be at the end. So that's a good planning range. In addition, we have one other project that we anticipate ITCs on this year in Virginia. It's a Eastern Shore project contracted with Amazon, and we would expect ITCs in a range of probably $0.06 to $0.08 from that project. So that makes up 2016. On 2017, I mentioned, if I recall on the January call that for planning purposes, we anticipate between $0.10 and $0.15 of ITCs in 2017 based on the activity that we knew of at that time. Since the first of the year, we've seen a tremendous amount of interest from a number of parties in Virginia, state government, military facilities, state centers and others to step up the generation solar build in Virginia. And I would expect that, that number for '17 are pretty easily double from that $0.10 to $0.15 and be in the $0.30 range based on the activity we know of today. Now we have not announced all the projects for 2017. But again, based on a pipeline of interest in the folks that we are discussing projects with, I would expect again ITCs in '17 probably now to range in the $0.30 range.

componenttextpreview: I wanted to discuss power demand growth outlook in Virginia. Just wonder if you could give us your latest thinking. We've heard from you before in terms of your overall take. But just curious what you're seeing lately in terms of the outlook for power dem
componenttext: I wanted to discuss power demand growth outlook in Virginia. Just wonder if you could give us your latest thinking. We've heard from you before in terms of your overall take. But just curious what you're seeing lately in terms of the outlook for power demand growth.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steven, this is Mark. Our view, as we've stated in the past, currently is is about a 1% power demand growth rate in the state. If you look at the first half of this year, it's been less than that. It's actually slightly down to the previous period, but th
componenttext: Steven, this is Mark. Our view, as we've stated in the past, currently is is about a 1% power demand growth rate in the state. If you look at the first half of this year, it's been less than that. It's actually slightly down to the previous period, but the mix is pretty interesting. For example, in the second quarter, although sales were down about 1% over a similar period last year, revenues were actually right at budget at about 1% higher, and that's because residential sales were very strong in the quarter. So we still believe that 1% sales growth over the next couple of years is certainly in the realm of possibility, and that's in our planning data. We would like to see stronger commercial sales growth outside of data centers. We think that will again be driven by spending from the government, where it was curtailed during the sequestration and starting to come back, but it's been slow. So we again believe that 1% growth is achievable and a realistic goal as we go forward.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: For the second quarter, weather normalized, residential sales were up 1.5%. Data centers were up almost 21%. Our commercial customers, excluding the data centers, were down about 3%. And industrial customers were down about 9%, and that's a very low perce
componenttext: For the second quarter, weather normalized, residential sales were up 1.5%. Data centers were up almost 21%. Our commercial customers, excluding the data centers, were down about 3%. And industrial customers were down about 9%, and that's a very low percentage of industrials. As you know, industrials make up a very small portion of our revenue streams, but they were down pretty strongly for the quarter.

componenttextpreview: Yes. So we're not going to do anything to affect our tax normalization Virginia Power in a regulated business -- the regulated part of the business unit. So if you do want to regulated entity, you cannot take advantage of the tax credit unless you do it t
componenttext: Yes. So we're not going to do anything to affect our tax normalization Virginia Power in a regulated business -- the regulated part of the business unit. So if you do want to regulated entity, you cannot take advantage of the tax credit unless you do it through a market-based rate. Two of the projects that were approved earlier this year, the Commission preferred a regulated rate of return. So those will not get -- we will not take advantage of the tax process. The military one that we announced this week, the Oceana Naval Air Station and the Amazon projects underway on the Eastern Shore are both going to be done through unregulated arms of the company, and we'll be able to take advantage of the tax credits. So most of the time, Mark mentioned there's been a tremendous uptick in interest in our customers in Virginia and elsewhere for us to participate in solar projects, and customers that we deal with in Virginia, but those same customers have been looking for us to do it elsewhere because we have a reputation of getting projects done on time and on budget. So we have a lot in the pipeline right now, but it will be a mix depending upon what the customers' needs are and where we are in the process.

componenttext: Greg, this is Mark. We'll be opportunistic on this. But there's a lot of interest in both from what we hear from bondholders and investors, and we'll go to market when we think the timing is right. We won't wait till it's much closer to Questar if we think we can go earlier.

At what point once we get through rest of the year see the Millstone hedges, get more visibility on solar, close Questar, are you going to be in a position to give a sort of a full some update on the outlook?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Greg, that will come after we give '17 guidance in January. We probably have to do that sometime early in 2017. We have 2 gating items here that we want to make sure are very comfortable with, and the first one is Cove Point, which is scheduled f
componenttext: I think, Greg, that will come after we give '17 guidance in January. We probably have to do that sometime early in 2017. We have 2 gating items here that we want to make sure are very comfortable with, and the first one is Cove Point, which is scheduled for late in 2017, and obviously, that is a huge driver for us, '18 and beyond. Project's going very well, but we'd like to get a little more construction down there. And then we also want to see the forward curves move much based on as we go into this winter, is '17 going to move or the whole curve going to move. So timing wise, I'd look for first half of 2017 for a more detailed outlook.

componenttext: Okay. And now given with what just happened in New York with the support for the Upstate New York nuclear plant, do you feel like there's going to be a similar move potentially impacting Millstone?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Connecticut legislature, Angie, as you know, the Senate unanimously passed a piece of legislation that's supported by Governor Malloy, and it came very late in the session. So the House didn't get to it. It's expected to come back in the session when
componenttext: The Connecticut legislature, Angie, as you know, the Senate unanimously passed a piece of legislation that's supported by Governor Malloy, and it came very late in the session. So the House didn't get to it. It's expected to come back in the session when they reconvene in the early part of 2017. It's a little bit different. New York is as I understand the New York piece is, is straight subsidy to the Upstate New York nuclear facilities. Connecticut has taken a different approach, which is to allow carbon-free production to bid into what has been satisfied just for renewables for the local utilities. So I think a very innovative approach and one that Millstone would participate in, and I think that last version of the legislation had half -- half of Millstone would be eligible to participate, which would be a good anchor for that plan. So yes, we expect to see more activity as we get into next year when the legislators come back to work.

componenttext: Well, I think as Mark said, we want to -- before we talk about '18, before we look at '18's hedges, we'll look at the forward curves. We'll also see the state of that legislation is because we want to be able to participate in the option if Millstone becomes eligible.

componenttextpreview: Angie, we -- I think we've always we said we'll consider selling almost any asset, but I think that is highly unlikely in this situation. Millstone is -- provides half of Connecticut's power. Connecticut has exactly 0 chance of meeting its carbon goals if
componenttext: Angie, we -- I think we've always we said we'll consider selling almost any asset, but I think that is highly unlikely in this situation. Millstone is -- provides half of Connecticut's power. Connecticut has exactly 0 chance of meeting its carbon goals if something were to take Millstone out of the energy mix in that state. It's got a very good plant, and it's got some economic challenges at the moment, but we have no -- we're not anticipate any consideration of selling it.

componenttext: Steve, this is Mark. Yes, the remaining -- the debt piece remaining as well, but what we said was we had about $2.4 million [ph] of financing, which we plan to split between mandatory convertibles at Dominion and equity and other resources at DM. But as part of our bridge financing, we have taken out a term loan or will, I should say, take out a term loan effective for 12 months at very attractive rates to us at close. So it gives us a lot of flexibility at DM on when we drop those assets into DM. We don't need to drop the assets to support our distribution growth rate until latter part of 2017. So we will be very opportunistic on DM on when we do that, and we may well utilize the term loan for a period of time to bridge the financing.

componenttext: Well, we haven't given, Brian, specific guidance for 2017 yet. The only thing we've done is we gave directional opportunities in February and March of 2015, where we showed potential growth rate, long term. What I would do if I was modeling this, I would go back to the end of 2014, see what the NEPOOL market price was then for 2017 and '18 and '19 and reference that to what the current strip is if you wanted to see a range of potential impacts for that one asset alone. So now again, that doesn't take into consideration other opportunities that have developed since our last Analyst Day. For example, capacity performance improvement that wasn't there before and other solar opportunities that we talk a lot about today. But for that one specific asset, I would look at the prices at the end of 2014 and reference that to whatever the market has today or whatever you believe the strip is going to be in January of next year.

componenttext: Sure. There's a couple of things there. I would say probably [indiscernible] more than anything, Jonathan, but I gave you little more color on it, $0.08. We also would expect that Questar will close by the fourth quarter, and we would see some potentially slight help from that, and we think we will have some financing savings as well as we move through the year based on our current plans versus our previous ones.

componenttext: I think that's probably right. We're very focused on O&M. If you look at the first 6 months of this year, we were -- versus the similar period last year, I think we were down about $0.06 on O&M. We're going to be down in O&M between now and the end of the year, and we're anticipating a recovery in weather, but we're a little weather short in the first 6 months versus norm. So we're very focused on that, and O&M is one of the levers that we're working on to try to offset some of these unforeseens.

componenttext: The plant, we're going to start commissioning the middle of next year. So you'll see that percentage continue to grow. We're in a part now, Jonathan, where you're laying the pipe racks and you're laying the conduits for the wiring and put the wiring in. That's all largely complete, but the concrete is all poured, for example, the sound wall has been finished. We don't have any hesitation that we're on time and on budget, and we will be ready to come online late next year.

componenttext: Just wanted to go over maybe the revised outlook for Blue Racer, given the fact that NGL prices have moved and propane and ethylene are a little bit stronger. Has your CapEx timing changed in terms of bringing on processing plants? And just your overall view of the wet gas unit kind of opportunities there.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neil, this is Mark. As we said over the last 6 to 9 months, Blue Racer, we should have had 5 processing plants online based on forecast that we put out at our Analyst Day 18 months ago. We only have 4 online although they are almost all at full capacity.
componenttext: Neil, this is Mark. As we said over the last 6 to 9 months, Blue Racer, we should have had 5 processing plants online based on forecast that we put out at our Analyst Day 18 months ago. We only have 4 online although they are almost all at full capacity. We have not seen a big step up based on current NGLs or oil in the basin, and we are being very cautious on Blue Racer to only invest capital when we have firm commitments from drillers. We have had some reach out from producers and drillers here in the last several months, been crying about their interest in moving ahead in the last half of this year, the first part of next year. But right now, I would say we're in a cautious mode of Blue Racer, and I don't expect new processing to be put in this year, maybe not for the first half of next year.

componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Tom Hamlin, Vice President of Investor Relations and Financial Planning, for the safe harbor statement.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call for Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners. During this call, we will refer to certain schedules included in this morning's earnings releases and pages from our Earn
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call for Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners. During this call, we will refer to certain schedules included in this morning's earnings releases and pages from our Earnings Release Kit. Schedules in the Earnings Release Kit are intended to answer the more detailed questions pertaining to operating statistics and accounting. Investor Relations will be available after the call for any clarification of these schedules. If you have not done so, I encourage you to visit the Investor Relations page on our website, register for e-mail alerts and view our second quarter earnings documents. Our website addresses are dom.com and dommidstream.com. In addition to the Earnings Release Kit, we have included a slide presentation on our website that will follow this morning's discussion.
And now for the usual cautionary language. The earnings releases and other matters that will be discussed on the call today may contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. Please refer to our SEC filings, including our most recent annual reports on Form 10-K and our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, for a discussion of factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecasts, estimates and expectations.
Also on this call, we will discuss some measures of our companies' performance that differ from those recognized by GAAP. Reconciliation of our non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures we are able to calculate and report are contained in the Earnings Release Kit and Dominion Midstream's press release.
Joining us on the call this morning, our CEO, Tom Farrell; our CFO, Mark McGettrick; and other members of our management team. Mark will discuss our earnings results for the second quarter and Dominion's earnings guidance for the third quarter and full year 2016. Tom will review our operating and regulatory activities and review the progress we've made on our growth plans. 
I will now turn the call over to Mark McGettrick.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Dominion Resources reported operating earnings of $0.71 per share for the second quarter of 2016, finishing in the upper half of our guidance range of $0.65 to $0.75 per share. Operating earnings would have been at the top of our guidance ra
componenttext:
Good morning. Dominion Resources reported operating earnings of $0.71 per share for the second quarter of 2016, finishing in the upper half of our guidance range of $0.65 to $0.75 per share. Operating earnings would have been at the top of our guidance range were it not for the impact of milder-than-normal weather and higher storm restoration costs. 
GAAP earnings were $0.73 per share for the second quarter. The principal difference between GAAP and operating earnings was a gain related to our investments in nuclear decommissioning trust funds. A reconciliation of operating earnings to reported earnings can be found on Schedule 2 of the Earnings Release Kit. 
Moving to results by operating segment. At Dominion Virginia Power, EBITDA for the second quarter was $363 million, which was in the lower half of its guidance range. Negative drivers for the quarter were higher major storm restoration costs and lower kilowatt-hour sales, primarily due to mild weather. These were partially offset by growth in rate base and lower operating expenses. 
Dominion Generation produced EBITDA of $509 million in the second quarter, which was in the upper half of its guidance range. Lower operating expenses and higher rider revenues offset lower-than-expected kilowatt-hour sales at Virginia Power. 
Second quarter EBITDA for Dominion Energy was $336 million, which was near the top of its guidance range. Lower operating expenses were the principal driver of the strong results. 
On a consolidated basis, interest expenses and income taxes were in line with our expectations. Overall, we were pleased with the performance of each of our operating segments. 
For the second quarter of 2016, Dominion Midstream Partners produced adjusted EBITDA of $27.2 million, 37% higher than the level produced in the second quarter of last year. Distributable cash flow increased 31% to $23.8 million, which was consistent with management's expectations. 
On July 22, Dominion Midstream's Board of Directors declared a distribution of $0.2355 per unit payable on August 15. This distribution represents a 5% increase over last quarter's payment and is consistent with our plan to achieve 22% annual distribution growth for LP units. 
Now moving to the cash flow and treasury activities at Dominion. Funds from operations were $2 billion for the first 6 months of the year. We have $5.5 billion of credit facilities, and taking into account restricted cash and short-term investments, we ended the quarter with liquidity of $2.8 billion. For statements of cash flow and liquidity, please see Pages 14 and 25 of the Earnings Release Kit. 
During the second quarter, we completed a number of financing transactions to support our growth plan and cover the acquisition of Questar. Slide 6 highlights our recent financing activities. We have a few debt financings planned for the remainder of the year, including issuances at Dominion and VEPCO. In addition, you should expect us to issue incremental mandatory convertible units to support the Questar transaction. 
Looking ahead to the third quarter, Dominion's operating earnings guidance is $0.95 to $1.10 per share. The midpoint of that range is unchanged from the operating earnings of $1.03 per share for the third quarter of 2015. Positive earnings drivers for the quarter compared to last year are higher revenues from our growth projects and lower capacity expenses for Virginia Power. Negative drivers for the quarter compared to last year include the absence of a farmout agreement and a higher share count. Dominion's operating earnings guidance for the year remains $3.60 to $4 per share. 
Slide 8 is an update of a slide we showed last quarter, which highlights the earnings drivers in the fourth quarter of 2016, which will allow us to achieve our annual guidance range. The chart begins with our actual operating earnings for the first half of 2016, plus the midpoint of our guidance for the third quarter. The middle of the chart details the positive and negative drivers for this year's fourth quarter relative to the prior year. We show about $0.07 per share of year-over-year negative drivers, principally financing costs and DD&A. We then highlight about $0.47 per share of year-over-year positive drivers in the fourth quarter, including normal weather, lower capacity expenses and the absence of a Millstone outage. 
As to hedging, you can find our hedge positions on Page 27 of the Earnings Release Kit. As of mid-July, we have hedged 95% of our expected 2016 production at Millstone and 8% of our expected 2017 production. 
So let me summarize my financial review. Operating earnings were $0.71 per share for the second quarter of 2016, which was in the upper half of our guidance range. Operating results for Dominion Midstream Partners were in line with management's expectations. And finally, Dominion's operating earnings guidance for the third quarter is $0.95 to $1.10 per share, and full year earnings guidance remains $3.60 to $4 per share. 
I will now turn the call over to Tom Farrell.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Strong operational and safety performance continued in the second quarter. All of our business units are on track to meet or exceed their safety goals for the year. Our nuclear fleet continues to operate well. The net capacity factor of our
componenttext:
Good morning. Strong operational and safety performance continued in the second quarter. All of our business units are on track to meet or exceed their safety goals for the year. Our nuclear fleet continues to operate well. The net capacity factor of our 6 units was 92% for the first 6 months of the year. The contribution of the Brunswick County power station helped our regulated power generation group achieve record net generation. 
Our Nuclear business unit completed 2 successful refueling outages in the second quarter. The outage at Millstone Unit 3 was completed in 34 days, and the refueling of Unit 2 at North Anna was completed in 35 days. 
Now for an update on our growth plans. The 1,358-megawatt Brunswick County power station began commercial operations in April, completing a construction schedule that began in August 2013 and was completed ahead of time and under budget. 
We have begun construction of the 1,588-megawatt Greensville County combined cycle power station. The air permit for the project was issued by the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality on June 17, and a full notice to proceed was given to Fluor that same day. The $1.3 billion project is expected to achieve commercial operations in late 2018. 
Construction on our 2 large contracted solar projects, Four Brothers and Three Cedars in Utah, continues on time and on budget. All sites are mechanically complete with grid synchronization underway. Both projects are expected to be in service this quarter. 
Virginia Governor Terry McAuliffe affirmed his intention for the Commonwealth to move forward on implementing the clean power plant in signing Executive Order 57 on June 28. The order set up an executive branch working group to identify executive actions that could be taken to reduce carbon emissions from the electric utility sector. Continued focus on carbon reduction, combined with demand for low carbon options by our customers, may require significant additional low or no-carbon power generation investment in Virginia. 
We have a number solar projects under development in the state today and continue to see demand for renewables from our customers, including data centers and military installations. Construction of the 80-megawatt solar facility on Virginia's Eastern Shore is underway and is expected be completed in the fourth quarter. The output from the Eastern Shore facility is under contract with our data center customer, Amazon. 
On June 30, Virginia State Corporation Commission approved 3 solar projects in Virginia. These facilities, totaling 56 megawatts, is also expected to be in service by late this year. We have filed with the State Corporation Commission for approval of an additional 20-megawatt solar facility at the site of our Remington power station to be in service next year. The output from this facility will be sold to the Commonwealth of Virginia, and the renewable energy credits will be sold to Microsoft. 
In July, we signed a lease with the Department of the Navy to develop an 18-megawatt solar facility at the Oceana Naval Air Station in Virginia Beach, and Monday filed for approval with the State Corporation Commission. The output of Oceana is under long-term contract with the Commonwealth of Virginia. If approved by the State Corporation Commission, this facility is expected to be in service by late next year. 
We have a number of electric transmission projects at various stages of regulatory approval and construction. $360 million worth of these facilities were completed in the second quarter, including our new systems operations center. We expect to place over $680 million of new transmission assets into service this year. 
An application for Phase 1 of our strategic distribution underground program was filed with the State Corporation Commission. Filing, which includes a cost-benefit analysis, covers 400 miles of distribution lines to be converted this year at a cost of $140 million, and SEC is expected to rule on the filing next month. 
Progress on our growth plan for Dominion Energy continues as well. Our Cove Point Liquefaction project is now 67% complete with over 1,800 construction workers on-site. Our engineering, procurement and structure contractor, IHI Kiewit, has installed well over half the 21,500 tons of the structural steel required, and the piping installation is proceeding on plan. We are on schedule to have all major equipment installation on foundations by end of the year. Our operations staffing plan is also on schedule. The formal classroom training began in the second quarter and will continue throughout the facility commissioning. Project continues on time and on budget for a late 2017 in-service date. 
We're continuing to work toward the commencement of construction on the Atlantic Coast Pipeline and the related Supply Header project. We made the formal FERC filings for these projects last September. In April, after submitting details of a reroute that avoid some sensitive areas within the United States Forest Service lands, we received a supplemental notice of intent to prepare an environmental impact statement. We have continued to respond to data request, and we were quite pleased with our progress at FERC. We anticipate receiving a scheduling order very soon followed by a permit, which will allow us to begin construction by mid-2017. Surveying and pipeline engineering is nearly complete and will be finished this year. Materials procurement is now over 80% complete, and we are finalizing our detailed construction plan. We expect completion of the Atlantic Coast Pipeline Supply Header in late 2018. 
The St. Charles Market Access project, delivering 132,000 dekatherms per day to a CPV power plant in Maryland, was completed June 1 on time and on budget. We currently have 4 projects under construction for an additional 600,000 dekatherms per day to come online later this year. 
In total, we have 10 pipeline growth projects underway in addition to the Atlantic Coast Pipeline Supply Header, with $1 billion of investment to move more than 1.5 billion cubic feet per day for customers by the end of 2018. The minority -- the majority of the projects are demand driven, moving gas to end-use power generation or local distribution companies. 
Turning to our farmout activity. We have enjoyed significant success with our Marcellus and Utica acreage farmout program, which began in 2013. Our current focus is on the portfolio of remaining Utica acreage packages and the prospect of restructuring a previously completed transactions. While many producers pulled back near-term drilling plans, there remains significant interest in several areas throughout our farmout program. 
During the second quarter, we restructured a previous agreement covering 79,000 acres of Marcellus shale development rights. As part of the restructuring, the parties have agreed to convey immediately a portion of the acreage to facilitate its development, resulting in the recognition of $36 million of revenue. We are currently in discussions with multiple parties and expect to realize additional value later this year. 
On March 31, Dominion filed its base rate case for our North Carolina service territory, seeking approval of a $51.1 million increase to base rate revenues based on a 10.5% return on equity. The North Carolina Commission issued a procedural order in May that calls for hearings in October. We have requested to implement the proposed rates subject to refund November 1 with permanent rates becoming effective January 1 of next year. 
Finally, I want to update you on our pending merger with Questar Corporation. Questar shareholders approved the transaction in May. Merger applications were filed with the Utah and Wyoming Public Service Commissions and notice was provided to the Idaho Commission. Technical conferences were completed last quarter, and discovery is almost complete. On August 1, we filed a settlement stipulation with the Wyoming Commission related to the merger. We will file supporting testimony on August 11 and will present the settlement to the Wyoming Commission on September 14. 
On July 28, we filed a rebuttal testimony with the Utah Commission. The hearing for that, the Commission has scheduled for August 22. We expect to close the transaction by year end. 
So to summarize, our business has delivered strong operating and safety performance in the second quarter with Brunswick County power station is now complete and in service, ahead of time and under budget. The Greensville County project has been approved, and construction is underway. The construction of the Cove Point Liquefaction project is on time and on budget. We continue to work toward FERC approval for the Atlantic Coast Pipeline and the Supply Header project, and we are working toward a successful close to our combination with Questar Corporation later this year. 
Thank you, and we are ready to take your questions.

componenttextpreview: So perhaps just a follow-up here. On 2017, can you elaborate a little bit on where you stand? Obviously, a little bit preempting guidance here later this year, but where do you stand relative to Millstone and hedging and provide a little bit more thought
componenttext: So perhaps just a follow-up here. On 2017, can you elaborate a little bit on where you stand? Obviously, a little bit preempting guidance here later this year, but where do you stand relative to Millstone and hedging and provide a little bit more thought on timing for hedging, given where the commodity markets have been this year?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julien, this is Mark. As you can see from our hedge schedules, we didn't hedge anything in the second quarter of this year, and we actually don't expect to hedge much in the third quarter of this year, either. Our view is that the oversupply that occurred
componenttext: Julien, this is Mark. As you can see from our hedge schedules, we didn't hedge anything in the second quarter of this year, and we actually don't expect to hedge much in the third quarter of this year, either. Our view is that the oversupply that occurred because a very mild winter and a very high production cycle over the last year or so is normalizing. And we think with a warm summer this year going into the fall, that storage will be full early, and we will see more bullish price signals in the Northeast as we go into the winter period. That being said, we've referenced a number of times that as we go into a calendar year and certainly by the, call it, the end of January, early February, we would expect Millstone to be hedged between 80% and 90%, which it always has been. But our hedge view is that we are going to wait till later this year to place more hedges on that facility.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, and therefore, holding off on providing any more formal commentary on '17, right?
componenttext: Got it, and therefore, holding off on providing any more formal commentary on '17, right?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right. I mean, we always give guidance for the calendar year typically in January, and that's still our view for 2017. But there's no question that the Millstone revenue streams driven by power prices are a big driver to '17, one way or the other,
componenttext: That's right. I mean, we always give guidance for the calendar year typically in January, and that's still our view for 2017. But there's no question that the Millstone revenue streams driven by power prices are a big driver to '17, one way or the other, and we want to get a very clear view on that before we give our annual guidance for 2017.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And also to clarify, I know you're trying to time things for hedges on '17. Just on going forward, what are your expectations for hedging policy? Anything beyond kind of year 1 hedge in January?
componenttext: And also to clarify, I know you're trying to time things for hedges on '17. Just on going forward, what are your expectations for hedging policy? Anything beyond kind of year 1 hedge in January?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we typically, over the years, have averaged hedges over a 3-year period pretty routinely, but we changed that about a year or so ago when we saw this very steep, very quick decline in power prices, which we do not think is sustainable. Obviously, to
componenttext: Well, we typically, over the years, have averaged hedges over a 3-year period pretty routinely, but we changed that about a year or so ago when we saw this very steep, very quick decline in power prices, which we do not think is sustainable. Obviously, too, Julien, you watch us closely that there's a lot of legislative activity occurring in the Northeast that could well impact nuclear and power prices in general. We want to see we can get a little more clarity on some of those activities. So we will be market sensitive to this. But unless the forward curves move, we're not going to be in a hurry to hedge right away beyond 2017.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just following up on a separate subject here. On ITCs, can you clarify a little bit, where do you stand on 2017 relative to plan? I know you guys talked about $0.10 to $0.15. You've announced a few projects, thus far, I think for next yea
componenttext: Got it. And then just following up on a separate subject here. On ITCs, can you clarify a little bit, where do you stand on 2017 relative to plan? I know you guys talked about $0.10 to $0.15. You've announced a few projects, thus far, I think for next year in VEPCO. And can you also clarify which projects qualify for the ITCs and which ones don't under your -- under VEPCO? And then maybe just a further detail, what's the total for '16 just to get it out there between VEPCO and GENCO.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's like 8 questions here, Julien, I think, but I'll be glad to answer all of them. Let's start with this year's ITCs based on the project that have been announced, and we talked about this on previous calls. The projects in Utah, which are very
componenttext: Okay. That's like 8 questions here, Julien, I think, but I'll be glad to answer all of them. Let's start with this year's ITCs based on the project that have been announced, and we talked about this on previous calls. The projects in Utah, which are very large projects, will produce between $0.30 and $0.35 of earnings from ITCs, and that range is really based on whatever the actual capital cost might be at the end. So that's a good planning range. In addition, we have one other project that we anticipate ITCs on this year in Virginia. It's a Eastern Shore project contracted with Amazon, and we would expect ITCs in a range of probably $0.06 to $0.08 from that project. So that makes up 2016. On 2017, I mentioned, if I recall, on the January call that for planning purposes, we anticipated between $0.10 and $0.15 of ITCs in 2017 based on the activity that we knew of at that time. Since the first of the year, we've seen a tremendous amount of interest from a number of parties in Virginia, state government, military facilities, data centers and others to step up the generation solar build in Virginia. And I would expect that, that number for '17 pretty easily double from that $0.10 to $0.15 and be in the $0.30 range based on the activity we know of today. Now we have not announced all the projects for 2017. But again, based on a pipeline of interest in the folks that we are discussing projects with, I would expect again ITCs in '17 probably now to range in the $0.30 range.

componenttextpreview: I wanted to discuss power demand growth outlook in Virginia. Just wonder if you could give us your latest thinking. We've heard from you before in terms of your overall take, but just curious what you're seeing lately in terms of the outlook for power dem
componenttext: I wanted to discuss power demand growth outlook in Virginia. Just wonder if you could give us your latest thinking. We've heard from you before in terms of your overall take, but just curious what you're seeing lately in terms of the outlook for power demand growth.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stephen, this is Mark. Our view, as we've stated in the past, currently is about a 1% power demand growth rate in the state. If you look at the first half of this year, it's been less than that. It's actually slightly down to the previous period, but the
componenttext: Stephen, this is Mark. Our view, as we've stated in the past, currently is about a 1% power demand growth rate in the state. If you look at the first half of this year, it's been less than that. It's actually slightly down to the previous period, but the mix is pretty interesting. For example, in the second quarter, although sales were down about 1% over a similar period last year, revenues were actually right at budget at about 1% higher, and that's because residential sales were very strong in the quarter. So we still believe that 1% sales growth over the next couple of years is certainly in the realm of possibility, and that's in our planning data. We would like to see stronger commercial sales growth outside of data centers. And we think that will again be driven by spending from the government, where it was curtailed during the sequestration and starting to come back, but it's been slow. So we again believe that 1% growth is achievable and a realistic goal as we go forward.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And weather adjusted for the quarter, how did it turn out in terms of maybe for residential and commercial in particular?
componenttext: Understood. And weather adjusted for the quarter, how did it turn out in terms of maybe for residential and commercial in particular?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: For the second quarter, weather normalized, residential sales were up 1.5%. Data centers were up almost 21%. Our commercial customers, excluding the data centers, were down about 3%. And industrial customers were down about 9%, and that's a very low perce
componenttext: For the second quarter, weather normalized, residential sales were up 1.5%. Data centers were up almost 21%. Our commercial customers, excluding the data centers, were down about 3%. And industrial customers were down about 9%, and that's a very low percentage of industrials. As you know, industrials make up a very small portion of our revenue streams, but they were down pretty strongly for the quarter.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: So when you talk about the demand for solar in Virginia and as I'm thinking about the different business units, VEPCO, gas operations, merchant power, should we assume that, that -- where will those projects reside? componenttext: Greg, it's likely to be a mix of both depending upon who the customer is and what their interest is. If you -- I rather, we can get into a discussion of tax normalization if you'd like, but I think it might mind numb everybody.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, please, let's not do that.
componenttext: Yes, please, let's not do that.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we're not going to do anything to affect our tax normalization at Virginia Power in a regulated business -- in the regulated part of the business unit. So if you do want to regulate an entity, you cannot take advantage of the tax credit unless you
componenttext: Yes. So we're not going to do anything to affect our tax normalization at Virginia Power in a regulated business -- in the regulated part of the business unit. So if you do want to regulate an entity, you cannot take advantage of the tax credit unless you do it through a market-based rate. Two of the projects that were approved earlier this year, the commission preferred a regulated rate of return. So those will not get -- we will not take advantage of the tax credits in that situation. The military one that we announced just this week at Oceana Naval Air Station and the Amazon project underway on the Eastern Shore are both going to be done through unregulated arms of the company, and we'll be able to take advantage of the tax credits. So most of the time, Mark mentioned there has been a tremendous uptick in interest in our customers in Virginia and elsewhere for us to participate in solar projects, and customers that we deal with in Virginia -- but those same customers have been looking for us to deal with elsewhere because we have a reputation of getting projects done on time and on budget. So we have a lot in the pipeline right now, but it will be a mix depending upon what the customers' needs are and where we are in the process.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's fortuitous because, obviously, with uncertainty around where the Millstone revenues are going to be, that could be a good substitute if power prices don't recover. Is that fair?
componenttext: Well, that's fortuitous because, obviously, with uncertainty around where the Millstone revenues are going to be, that could be a good substitute if power prices don't recover. Is that fair?
