headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So perhaps just a follow-up here. On 2017, can you elaborate a little bit on where you stand? Obviously, a little bit preempting guidance here later this year, but where do you stand relative to Millstone and hedging and provide a little bit more thought
componenttext: So perhaps just a follow-up here. On 2017, can you elaborate a little bit on where you stand? Obviously, a little bit preempting guidance here later this year, but where do you stand relative to Millstone and hedging and provide a little bit more thought on timing for hedging, given where the commodity markets have been this year?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julien, this is Mark. As you can see from our hedge schedules, we didn't hedge anything in the second quarter of this year, and we actually don't expect to hedge much in the third quarter of this year, either. Our view is that the oversupply that occurred
componenttext: Julien, this is Mark. As you can see from our hedge schedules, we didn't hedge anything in the second quarter of this year, and we actually don't expect to hedge much in the third quarter of this year, either. Our view is that the oversupply that occurred because a very mild winter and a very high production cycle over the last year or so is normalizing. And we think with a warm summer this year going into the fall, that storage will be full early, and we will see more bullish price signals in the Northeast as we go into the winter period. That being said, we've referenced a number of times that as we go into a calendar year and certainly by the, call it, the end of January, early February, we would expect Millstone to be hedged between 80% and 90%, which it always has been. But our hedge view is that we are going to wait till later this year to place more hedges on that facility.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, and therefore, holding off on providing any more formal commentary on '17, right?
componenttext: Got it, and therefore, holding off on providing any more formal commentary on '17, right?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right. I mean, we always give guidance for the calendar year typically in January, and that's still our view for 2017. But there's no question that the Millstone revenue streams driven by power prices are a big driver to '17, one way or the other,
componenttext: That's right. I mean, we always give guidance for the calendar year typically in January, and that's still our view for 2017. But there's no question that the Millstone revenue streams driven by power prices are a big driver to '17, one way or the other, and we want to get a very clear view on that before we give our annual guidance for 2017.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And also to clarify, I know you're trying to time things for hedges on '17. Just on going forward, what are your expectations for hedging policy? Anything beyond kind of year 1 hedge in January?
componenttext: And also to clarify, I know you're trying to time things for hedges on '17. Just on going forward, what are your expectations for hedging policy? Anything beyond kind of year 1 hedge in January?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we typically, over the years, have averaged hedges over a 3-year period pretty routinely, but we changed that about a year or so ago when we saw this very steep, very quick decline in power prices, which we do not think is sustainable. Obviously, to
componenttext: Well, we typically, over the years, have averaged hedges over a 3-year period pretty routinely, but we changed that about a year or so ago when we saw this very steep, very quick decline in power prices, which we do not think is sustainable. Obviously, too, Julien, you watch us closely that there's a lot of legislative activity occurring in the Northeast that could well impact nuclear and power prices in general. We want to see we can get a little more clarity on some of those activities. So we will be market sensitive to this. But unless the forward curves move, we're not going to be in a hurry to hedge right away beyond 2017.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just following up on a separate subject here. On ITCs, can you clarify a little bit, where do you stand on 2017 relative to plan? I know you guys talked about $0.10 to $0.15. You've announced a few projects, thus far, I think for next yea
componenttext: Got it. And then just following up on a separate subject here. On ITCs, can you clarify a little bit, where do you stand on 2017 relative to plan? I know you guys talked about $0.10 to $0.15. You've announced a few projects, thus far, I think for next year in VEPCO. And can you also clarify which projects qualify for the ITCs and which ones don't under your -- under VEPCO? And then maybe just a further detail, what's the total for '16 just to get it out there between VEPCO and GENCO.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's like 8 questions here, Julien, I think, but I'll be glad to answer all of them. Let's start with this year's ITCs based on the project that have been announced, and we talked about this on previous calls. The projects in Utah, which are very
componenttext: Okay. That's like 8 questions here, Julien, I think, but I'll be glad to answer all of them. Let's start with this year's ITCs based on the project that have been announced, and we talked about this on previous calls. The projects in Utah, which are very large projects, will produce between $0.30 and $0.35 of earnings from ITCs, and that range is really based on whatever the actual capital cost might be at the end. So that's a good planning range. In addition, we have one other project that we anticipate ITCs on this year in Virginia. It's a Eastern Shore project contracted with Amazon, and we would expect ITCs in a range of probably $0.06 to $0.08 from that project. So that makes up 2016. On 2017, I mentioned, if I recall, on the January call that for planning purposes, we anticipated between $0.10 and $0.15 of ITCs in 2017 based on the activity that we knew of at that time. Since the first of the year, we've seen a tremendous amount of interest from a number of parties in Virginia, state government, military facilities, data centers and others to step up the generation solar build in Virginia. And I would expect that, that number for '17 pretty easily double from that $0.10 to $0.15 and be in the $0.30 range based on the activity we know of today. Now we have not announced all the projects for 2017. But again, based on a pipeline of interest in the folks that we are discussing projects with, I would expect again ITCs in '17 probably now to range in the $0.30 range.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttextpreview: I wanted to discuss power demand growth outlook in Virginia. Just wonder if you could give us your latest thinking. We've heard from you before in terms of your overall take, but just curious what you're seeing lately in terms of the outlook for power dem
componenttext: I wanted to discuss power demand growth outlook in Virginia. Just wonder if you could give us your latest thinking. We've heard from you before in terms of your overall take, but just curious what you're seeing lately in terms of the outlook for power demand growth.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stephen, this is Mark. Our view, as we've stated in the past, currently is about a 1% power demand growth rate in the state. If you look at the first half of this year, it's been less than that. It's actually slightly down to the previous period, but the
componenttext: Stephen, this is Mark. Our view, as we've stated in the past, currently is about a 1% power demand growth rate in the state. If you look at the first half of this year, it's been less than that. It's actually slightly down to the previous period, but the mix is pretty interesting. For example, in the second quarter, although sales were down about 1% over a similar period last year, revenues were actually right at budget at about 1% higher, and that's because residential sales were very strong in the quarter. So we still believe that 1% sales growth over the next couple of years is certainly in the realm of possibility, and that's in our planning data. We would like to see stronger commercial sales growth outside of data centers. And we think that will again be driven by spending from the government, where it was curtailed during the sequestration and starting to come back, but it's been slow. So we again believe that 1% growth is achievable and a realistic goal as we go forward.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And weather adjusted for the quarter, how did it turn out in terms of maybe for residential and commercial in particular?
componenttext: Understood. And weather adjusted for the quarter, how did it turn out in terms of maybe for residential and commercial in particular?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: For the second quarter, weather normalized, residential sales were up 1.5%. Data centers were up almost 21%. Our commercial customers, excluding the data centers, were down about 3%. And industrial customers were down about 9%, and that's a very low perce
componenttext: For the second quarter, weather normalized, residential sales were up 1.5%. Data centers were up almost 21%. Our commercial customers, excluding the data centers, were down about 3%. And industrial customers were down about 9%, and that's a very low percentage of industrials. As you know, industrials make up a very small portion of our revenue streams, but they were down pretty strongly for the quarter.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we're not going to do anything to affect our tax normalization at Virginia Power in a regulated business -- in the regulated part of the business unit. So if you do want to regulate an entity, you cannot take advantage of the tax credit unless you
componenttext: Yes. So we're not going to do anything to affect our tax normalization at Virginia Power in a regulated business -- in the regulated part of the business unit. So if you do want to regulate an entity, you cannot take advantage of the tax credit unless you do it through a market-based rate. Two of the projects that were approved earlier this year, the commission preferred a regulated rate of return. So those will not get -- we will not take advantage of the tax credits in that situation. The military one that we announced just this week at Oceana Naval Air Station and the Amazon project underway on the Eastern Shore are both going to be done through unregulated arms of the company, and we'll be able to take advantage of the tax credits. So most of the time, Mark mentioned there has been a tremendous uptick in interest in our customers in Virginia and elsewhere for us to participate in solar projects, and customers that we deal with in Virginia -- but those same customers have been looking for us to deal with elsewhere because we have a reputation of getting projects done on time and on budget. So we have a lot in the pipeline right now, but it will be a mix depending upon what the customers' needs are and where we are in the process.

componenttext: Great. And when do you think we'll have some clarity around the timing of the financing plan for Questar? It doesn't sound like you're looking at any significant roadblocks to closing by year end. Should we presume that the timing of the converts come around the time of close? Or will you be more opportunistic like, for instance, NextEra, which is prefunding the Encore deal even though they're on a go-shop period.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, this is Mark. We'll be opportunistic on this. We have some Dominion debt to issue still, and we have some converts to issue still. And we will be utilizing the market for that here over the next several months. But there's a lot of interest in both
componenttext: Greg, this is Mark. We'll be opportunistic on this. We have some Dominion debt to issue still, and we have some converts to issue still. And we will be utilizing the market for that here over the next several months. But there's a lot of interest in both from what we hear from bondholders and investors, and we'll go to market when we think the timing is right. We won't wait till it's much closer to Questar if we think we can go earlier.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And my last question is, as sort of your last investor presentation, the May deck, you're still pointing to the consistent earnings and dividend growth profile as outlined in your Analyst Day from a year ago, February. At what point once we get thr
componenttext: Right. And my last question is, as sort of your last investor presentation, the May deck, you're still pointing to the consistent earnings and dividend growth profile as outlined in your Analyst Day from a year ago, February. At what point once we get through the rest of the year, see the Millstone hedges, get more visibility on solar, close Questar, are you going to be in a position to give us sort of a fulsome update on the outlook?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Greg, that will come after we give '17 guidance in January. We probably have to do that sometime early in 2017. We have 2 gating items here that we want to make sure we're very comfortable with, and the first one is Cove Point, which is scheduled
componenttext: I think, Greg, that will come after we give '17 guidance in January. We probably have to do that sometime early in 2017. We have 2 gating items here that we want to make sure we're very comfortable with, and the first one is Cove Point, which is scheduled for late in 2017, and obviously, that is a huge driver for us, '18 and beyond. Project is going very well, but we'd like to get a little more construction down there. And then we also want to see to the forward curves move much based on as we go into this winter, is '17 going to move or is the whole curve going to move. So again, timing wise, I'd look for first half of 2017 for a more detailed outlook.

componenttext: Angie, it's Mark. I don't, right now, anticipate unless the forward curves move significantly and we have hedged Millstone that we will give any new update on '18 and beyond when we give '17 guidance in January.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And now given with what just happened in New York with the support for the Upstate New York nuclear plant, do you feel like there's going to be a similar move potentially impacting Millstone?
componenttext: Okay. And now given with what just happened in New York with the support for the Upstate New York nuclear plant, do you feel like there's going to be a similar move potentially impacting Millstone?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Connecticut legislature, Angie, as you know, the Senate unanimously passed a piece of legislation that's supported by Governor Malloy, and it came very late in the session, so the House didn't get to it. It's expected to come back in the session when
componenttext: The Connecticut legislature, Angie, as you know, the Senate unanimously passed a piece of legislation that's supported by Governor Malloy, and it came very late in the session, so the House didn't get to it. It's expected to come back in the session when they reconvene in the early part of 2017. It's a little bit different. New York is -- I understand the New York PC is a straight subsidy to the Upstate New York nuclear facilities. Connecticut has taken a different approach, which is to allow carbon-free production to bid into what has been satisfied just for renewables for the local utilities. It's I think a very innovative approach and one that Millstone would participate in. And I think the last version of the legislation had half -- up to half of Millstone would be eligible to participate, which would be a good anchor for that plan. So yes, we expect to see more activity as we get into next year when the legislators come back to work.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: But it has no bearing on your -- on the hedging of the plans?
componenttext: But it has no bearing on your -- on the hedging of the plans?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, as Mark said, we're going to -- we want to -- before we talk about '18, before we look at '18's hedges, we'll look at the forward curves and we'll also see what state that legislation is because we want to be able to participate in the auct
componenttext: Well, I think, as Mark said, we're going to -- we want to -- before we talk about '18, before we look at '18's hedges, we'll look at the forward curves and we'll also see what state that legislation is because we want to be able to participate in the auction if Millstone becomes eligible.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the last question, would you consider potentially selling the plant to an operator with a larger suite of nuclear plants?
componenttext: Okay. And the last question, would you consider potentially selling the plant to an operator with a larger suite of nuclear plants?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Angie, we -- I think we've always -- we said we'll consider selling most any asset, but I think that is highly unlikely in this situation. Millstone is -- provides half of Connecticut's power. Connecticut has exactly 0 chance of meeting its carbon goals,
componenttext: Angie, we -- I think we've always -- we said we'll consider selling most any asset, but I think that is highly unlikely in this situation. Millstone is -- provides half of Connecticut's power. Connecticut has exactly 0 chance of meeting its carbon goals, if something were to take Millstone out of the energy mix in that state. It's a very good plant, and it's got some economic challenges at the moment. But we have no -- we're not anticipating any consideration of selling it.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steve Fleishman with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steve Fleishman with Wolfe Research.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one other clarity on the financing of Questar. So the remaining financing was going to be converts and still DM drop-down. So do you still plan to do some drops into DM later this year related to that?
componenttext: Just one other clarity on the financing of Questar. So the remaining financing was going to be converts and still DM drop-down. So do you still plan to do some drops into DM later this year related to that?

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, this is Mark. Yes, the remaining -- there's a debt piece remaining as well, but what we said was we had about $2.4 million of financing, which we plan to split between mandatory convertibles at Dominion and equity and other sources at DM. But as pa
componenttext: Steve, this is Mark. Yes, the remaining -- there's a debt piece remaining as well, but what we said was we had about $2.4 million of financing, which we plan to split between mandatory convertibles at Dominion and equity and other sources at DM. But as part of our bridge financing, we have taken out a term loan or will, I should say, take out a term loan effective for 12 months at very attractive rates to us at close. So it gives us a lot of flexibility at DM on when we drop those assets into DM. We don't need to drop the assets to support our distribution growth rate until latter part of 2017. So we will be very opportunistic on DM when we do that, and we may well utilize the term loan for a period of time to bridge the financing.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I guess, my other question just to kind of fill in the discussion more on new solar. What would be -- because, obviously, it'd be helpful to get the ITCs and the other part is though you do have -- you would have a lot more capital need, I assume. S
componenttext: Okay. I guess, my other question just to kind of fill in the discussion more on new solar. What would be -- because, obviously, it'd be helpful to get the ITCs and the other part is though you do have -- you would have a lot more capital need, I assume. So could you give a sense to get to the $0.30 or double, just like how much more capital spend might that require?

componenttext: Well, we haven't given, Brian, specific guidance for 2017 yet. The only thing we've done is we gave directional opportunities in February and March of 2015, where we showed potential growth rate long term. What I would do if I was modeling this, I would go back to the end of 2014, see what the NEPOOL market price was then for 2017 and '18 and '19 and reference that to what the current strip is if you wanted to see a range of potential impacts for that one asset alone. So now again, that doesn't take into consideration other opportunities that have developed since our last Analyst Day, for example, capacity performance improvement that wasn't there before and other solar opportunities that we talked a lot about today. But for that one specific asset, I would look at the prices at the end of 2014 and reference that to whatever the market has today or whatever you believe the strip is going to be in January of next year.

headline: Dominion Resources, Inc., Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neel, this is Mark. And as we said over the last 6 to 9 months, Blue Racer, we should have had 5 processing plants online based on forecast that we put out at our Analyst Day 18 months ago. We only have 4 online although they are almost all at full capaci
componenttext: Neel, this is Mark. And as we said over the last 6 to 9 months, Blue Racer, we should have had 5 processing plants online based on forecast that we put out at our Analyst Day 18 months ago. We only have 4 online although they are almost all at full capacity. We have not seen a big step up based on current NGLs or oil in the basin, and we are being very cautious on Blue Racer to only invest capital when we have firm commitments from drillers. We have had some reach out from producers and drillers here in the last several months inquiring about their interest in moving ahead in the last half of this year and first part of next year. But right now, I would say we're in a cautious mode on Blue Racer, and I don't expect new processing to be put in this year, maybe not for the first half of next year.

headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: [ph] Good afternoon, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call for Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners.During this call, we will refer to certain schedules included in this morning's earnings releases and pages from o
componenttext:
[ph] Good afternoon, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call for Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners.
During this call, we will refer to certain schedules included in this morning's earnings releases and pages from our Earnings Release Kit. [ph] Schedules in the Earnings Release Kit are intended to answer the more detailed questions pertaining to operating statistics and accounting. Investor Relations will be available after the call for any clarification of these schedules. If you've not done so, I encourage you to visit the Investor Relations page on our websites, register for e-mail alerts and view our third quarter earnings documents. Our website addresses are dom.com and dommidstream.com.
In addition to the Earnings Release Kit, we have included a slide presentation on our website that will follow this morning's discussion.
And now for the usual cautionary language. The earnings releases and other matters that will be discussed on the call today may contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. Please refer to our SEC filings, including our most recent annual reports on Form 10-K and our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q for a discussion of factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecast, estimates and expectations.
Also on this call, we will discuss some measures of our company's performance that differ from those recognized by GAAP. Reconciliation of our non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures we are able to calculate and report are contained in the Earnings Release Kit and Dominion Midstream's press release.
Joining us on the call this afternoon are our CEO, Tom Farrell; our CFO, Mark McGettrick; [ph] and other members of our management team. Mark will discuss our earnings results for the third quarter and Dominion's earnings guidance for the fourth quarter. He will also discuss Dominion Midstream's financing of its planned acquisition of Questar pipeline, [ph] which was priced this morning. Tom will review our operating and regulatory activities and review the progress we have made on our growth plans.
I will now turn the call over to Mark McGettrick.

headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Dominion Resources reported operating earnings of $1.14 per share for the third quarter of 2016, finishing well above the top of our guidance range. Positive factors relative to guidance for the quarter were favorable weather, lower operat
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Dominion Resources reported operating earnings of $1.14 per share for the third quarter of 2016, finishing well above the top of our guidance range. Positive factors relative to guidance for the quarter were favorable weather, lower operating expenses, an earlier approval of our Questar acquisition and partnership income from one of our large solar projects. Some of the partnership income is timing related and will reverse in the fourth quarter.
Negative factors were an unplanned outage at Millstone [ph] and higher major storm restoration costs.
GAAP earnings were $1.10 per share for the third quarter. The principal difference between GAAP and operating earnings were charges related to transaction costs for our merger with Questar. A reconciliation of operating earnings to reported earnings can be found on Schedule 2 of the Earnings Release Kit.
Moving to results by operating segment. At Dominion Virginia Power, [ph] EBITDA for the third quarter was $423 million, which was in the upper half of its guidance range. Favorable weather conditions were partially offset by higher major storm restoration costs. Dominion Generation [ph] produced EBITDA of $921 million in the third quarter, which exceeded the top of its guidance range. Favorable weather was the principal factor in the strong performance, partially offset by an unplanned outage at Millstone.
Third quarter EBITDA for Dominion Energy [ph] was $310 million, which was above the top of its guidance range. Lower operating expenses and an earlier-than-planned contribution from Questar were the principal drivers of the strong results. Overall, we are very pleased with the performance of each of our operating segments.
For the third quarter of 2016, Dominion Midstream Partners produced adjusted EBITDA of $27.9 million, 37% higher than the level produced in the third quarter of last year. Distributable cash flow increased 22% to $24.1 million, which was consistent with management's expectations.
On October 21, Dominion Midstream's Board of Directors declared a distribution of $0.2475 per unit payable on November 15. This distribution represents a 5% increase over last quarter's payment and is consistent with our plan to achieve 22% annual distribution growth for LP [ph] units.
Moving to cash flow and treasury activities at Dominion. Funds from operations were $3.1 billion for the first 9 months of the year. We have $5.5 billion of credit facilities, and taking into account cash, short-term investments and commercial paper outstanding, we ended the quarter with available liquidity of $2.5 billion.
For statements of cash flow and liquidity, please see Pages 14 and 25 of the Earnings Release Kit.
During the third quarter, we completed a number of financing transactions to support our growth plan and cover the acquisition of Questar. Slide 6 highlights our recent financing activities. We have one public debt financing plan for the remainder of this year at devco.[ph] 
Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, Dominion's operating earnings guidance is $0.90 to $1.05 per share. The midpoint of that range is $0.28 per share above operating earnings of $0.70 per share for the fourth quarter of 2015. Positive earnings drivers for the quarter compared to last year are return to normal weather, the absence of refueling outage at Millstone, lower capacity expenses and the addition of Questar. Negative drivers for the quarter compared to last year include higher financing costs and DD&A.
Dominion's operating earnings guidance for the year remains $3.60 to $4 per share.
As to hedging, you can find our hedge positions on Page 27 of the Earnings Release Kit. As of mid-October, we have hedged 8% of our expected 2017 production at Millstone. We expect to add to our hedges over the next 3 months and plan to have about 80% of our 2017 production hedged by the end of January.
So let me summarize my financial review. Operating earnings were $1.14 per share for the third quarter of 2016, which was well above our guidance range. Operating results for Dominion Midstream Partners were in line with management's expectations. And finally, Dominion's operating earnings guidance for the fourth quarter is $0.90 to $1.05 per share and full year earnings guidance remains $3.60 to $4 per share.
I will now turn the call over to Tom Farrell.

headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Strong operational and safety performance continued in the third quarter. All of our business units are on track to meet their safety goals for the year. We expect to set another company-wide safety record this year.Our nuclear fleet con
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Strong operational and safety performance continued in the third quarter. All of our business units are on track to meet their safety goals for the year. We expect to set another company-wide safety record this year.
Our nuclear fleet continues to operate well. The net capacity factor of our 6 units was 93% for the first 9 months of the year. The contribution of the Brunswick County Power Station [ph] helped our regulated power generation group achieve record net generation.
Now for an update on our growth plans. Construction of the 1,588 [ph] megawatt Greensville County [ph] combined cycle power station continues on time and on budget. Approximately 480 workers are on site performing civil and structural work. The $1.3 billion project is expected to achieve commercial operations in late 2018.
Our 2 large contracted solar projects, Four Brothers and Three Cedars in Utah, were completed in September on time and on budget. We own 50% of the 2 projects that have a combined capacity of 530 megawatts and are secured by 20-year power purchase agreements.
We have a number of solar projects under development in the state of Virginia and continue to see demand for renewables from our customers, including data centers, military installations and the state government. The 80-megawatt solar facility under Virginia's Eastern Shore is complete and went into service over this past weekend. 3 other Virginia solar projects totaling 56 megawatts are also expected to be in service by year-end.
Earlier this month, we announced a 60-megawatt solar development in North Carolina, secured by 25-year power purchase agreements. This project should also be in service by the end of this year.
We have filed with State Corporation Commission for approval of an additional 20-megawatt solar facility at the sight of our Remington Power Station to be in service next year. In July, we signed a lease with the Department of the Navy [ph] to develop an 18-megawatt solar facility at the Oceana Naval Air Station [ph] in Virginia. If approved by the State Corporation Commission, this solar facility is expected to be in service by late next year. This will bring our operating solar fleet to 1,200 megawatts by the end of 2017.
We are in discussions with multiple parties for further solar development in the future, and we fully expect to exceed our goal of adding 500 megawatts of solar farms in Virginia and North Carolina. We have a number of electric transmission projects at various stages of regulatory approval and construction. $580 million worth of these facilities have been completed so far this year, including our new systems operations center.
We expect to place over $730 million of new transmission assets into service by year-end.
Progress on our growth plan for Dominion Energy continues as well. Our Cove Point Liquefaction project is now 75% complete with over 2,000 construction workers on site. Our engineering, procurement and construction contractor, IHI Kiewit, has installed well over half of the 21,500 tons [ph] of the structural steel required, and the piping installation is proceeding on plan.
All major components have been delivered to the site, and all will be installed under foundations by year-end. Our operations staffing plan is also on schedule. The project continues to be on time and on budget for a late 2017 in-service date.
We're continuing to work toward the commencement of construction on the Atlantic Coast Pipeline and the related Supply Header project. FERC issued its notice of schedule on August 12. We expect to receive the draft EIS in a few weeks and the final EIS in June. We anticipate beginning construction upon receipt of the first certificate during the second half of next year. Surveying and pipeline engineering is nearly complete and will be finished this year. We're finalizing our detailed construction plans and on September 16, executed the construction contract with Spring Ridge constructors. [ph] We expect completion of the Atlantic Coast Pipeline and Supply Header in the second half of 2019.
In addition to the Atlantic Coast Pipeline and Supply Header, we have 10 pipeline growth projects underway with $1 billion of investment to move 1.5 million [ph] cubic feet per day per customers by the end of 2018. Our Monroe to Cornwell project, with more than 200,000 dekatherms [ph] per day of capacity, was put into service in October, and we have another 3 projects to come online this year. Our new expansion projects are primarily demand driven, moving gas to engine [ph] power generators for local distribution companies.
In regulatory matters, hearings were held earlier this month for Dominion's base rate case for our North Carolina service territories, seeking approval of a $51.1 million increase in base rate revenues. A settlement was reached with the staff and a group of investor [ph] customers calling for a $34.7 million increase based on a 9.9% return on equity. We will implement the proposed rates subject to refund tomorrow with permanent rates becoming effective January 1 of next year. A decision is expected in December. 
Finally, I want to update you on our merger with Questar Corporation. The Public Service Commission of Utah approved the merger on August 23, and the Wyoming Public Service Commission approved it on September 14. We completed the merger 2 days later. Ron Jibson, [ph] Questar's retired Chairman and CEO, has joined Dominion's Board of Directors. Harry Simmons, [ph] the former Lead Director for Questar, has joined the board of Dominion Midstream Partners. We are excited about adding Questar to Dominion's operations and look forward to developing new growth opportunities in the Western states.
So to summarize, our business has delivered strong operating and safety performance in the third quarter. Construction of the Greensville County project is on time and on budget. Construction of the Cove Point Liquefaction project is on time and on budget. We continue to work toward FERC approval for the Atlantic Coast Pipeline and the Supply Header project, and we are excited about our future opportunities that will come as a result of our merger with Questar.
I will now return the call to Mark for a discussion of our financings at Dominion Midstream Partners.

headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom. We issued press releases this morning announcing the launch and subsequent pricing of Dominion Midstream financing to acquire Questar Pipeline.I wanted to discuss it on this afternoon's call for a number of reasons. First, it represents
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. We issued press releases this morning announcing the launch and subsequent pricing of Dominion Midstream financing to acquire Questar Pipeline.
I wanted to discuss it on this afternoon's call for a number of reasons. First, it represents one of the largest financing transactions by a publicly traded MLP this year. Second, based on the low initial yield for the preferred equity and the modest discount to market for the common units, this financing was the least expensive for an MLP issuer this year. It provides clear evidence of the high level of interest by investors in DM equity. Third, despite being one of the largest offerings this year, demand for the common equity was significantly oversubscribed, leading us to upsize the offering. Fourth, this successful financing validates our strategic plan for Dominion Midstream Partners, which involves accessing capital markets on advantageous terms to fund the acquisition of midstream assets of Dominion that will, in turn, support a 22% annual distribution growth rate. And finally, this successful financing and low achieved [ph] yields confirm the value-accretive proposition underlying the formation of Dominion Midstream 2 years ago for investors of both D and DM.
As noted in this morning's press releases, Dominion Midstream Partners will acquire 100% interest in Questar Pipeline on or about December 1 for an implied enterprise value of $1.725 billion or about 10.3x 2016 EBITDA. About $435 million of existing long-term debt will remain in place at Questar Pipeline, leaving net consideration of just about $1.3 billion.
As announced this morning, we have priced a common unit offering, including both an underwritten offering and a private placement, totaling some $500 million assuming underwriters exercise the greenshoot [ph] option. Again, I would note that this common unit offering registers as one of the largest MLP unit offerings of the year and at just 2.9% reflects by far the smallest discount to any trade of any offering this year.
We have also received commitments from a group of private investors, led by Stone Peak Infrastructure Partners, [ph] for up to $600 million in convertible preferred securities, which was priced together with this morning's offering and which closes in conjunction with the transaction at the [ph] close on December 1. Among comparable securities offered by MLPs, this preferred security has the lowest-ever initial yield of 4.75% and an attractive conversion premium of 15%.
It is clear from the interest in DM preferred structure that investors see very high growth potential in DM shares. We very much appreciate the overwhelming interest and participation in this offering from both public and private investors.
At closing, the cash consideration to Dominion provided by these offerings will be used to repay existing Dominion level debt. We will also refinance the existing DM intercompany note with a 3-year term note from a group of banks.
As shown on Slide 19, including a $1.2 billion of proceeds from this transaction, we expect the MLP to generate about $7 billion to $8 billion in cash for Dominion through 2020, which we'll use to reduce holding company debt, increase dividends, invest in new growth projects and repurchase common stock.
We realize that D, DM structure is somewhat unique in the utility space, and investors have been waiting for us to begin to execute a drop-down strategy. We expect that with the success of today's transactions, both D and DM investors will see the clear long-term growth and value for both shareholders and unitholders.
With that, we'll be happy to take your questions.

headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016

headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julien, this is Mark. The answer to the first part of your question is it's regardless of what the market power price will be between now and the end of January. We committed over many years to investors and the credit agencies that there will be a clear
componenttext: Julien, this is Mark. The answer to the first part of your question is it's regardless of what the market power price will be between now and the end of January. We committed over many years to investors and the credit agencies that there will be a clear firm cash flow stream from Millstone as we put guidance out in the current period. So we have always hedged Millstone in the 80-plus-percent range by the end of the year call, and we plan on doing the same for 2017. In terms of future periods, we will be very cautious on hedging Millstone for a number of reasons. One is we believe that the current forward strip is dramatically understating the value of the market; and second, as you know, there is a lot of discussion in Connecticut about potential legislation and [ph] the ability to Millstone bid into future auctions. We hope that would be cleared up in the first half of next year, and we would want to see what the outcome of that would be before we hedge 2018 and beyond.

headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julien, we -- the more we look, the more opportunities we see. The West -- that part of the West is largely powered by coal-fired power plants. Many of them are going to have to close or be converted to natural gas. There's an increasing amount of RPS [ph
componenttext: Julien, we -- the more we look, the more opportunities we see. The West -- that part of the West is largely powered by coal-fired power plants. Many of them are going to have to close or be converted to natural gas. There's an increasing amount of RPS [ph] requirements in states on -- particularly on the Western Seacoast [ph] where, as you know and I think investors know, the more renewables that are built, the more gas-fired peakers are going to be required to deal with the fact that it's intermittent. So that's just one potential opportunity that we see in the West. There's a lot of natural gas infrastructure that's going to be required in the future there. Now it's not on the same scale obviously as the mid-Atlantic [ph] as far as population goes, but starting from the base that we have in the West, we think there's a tremendous amount of opportunity.

headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, our targets will be unchanged. And I think your reference is that the IRS after this calendar year do not allow certain tax shields that existed prior to that MLPs could make themselves available to, but we have a long-term tax planning for each of t
componenttext: Yes, our targets will be unchanged. And I think your reference is that the IRS after this calendar year do not allow certain tax shields that existed prior to that MLPs could make themselves available to, but we have a long-term tax planning for each of the years through 2020. We were aware of that potential down the road, and it will not impact either our growth rate or our distribution focus going forward. That has been incorporated into our tax planning for quite some time.

componenttext: Sure, Steve. This solar involves partnership income from one project, Four Brothers in Utah, and it's complicated partnership accounting. When we put the guidance out -- and actually we put the budget together this year, we thought the contribution would be evenly distributed over a number of quarters, but the final accounting determination required us to book $0.04 in the third quarter, and that will roll off [ph] $0.02 in the fourth quarter and $0.02 in the first half of next year. So that's a timing issue for the quarter, but for year-end, there is no impact on our guidance at all.

headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's more of the latter. We really believe we have overhang of both these stocks based on an anticipated offering at DM. We also -- I think, as I mentioned earlier, people have been waiting for us to validate the structure of D and DM and those advantages
componenttext: It's more of the latter. We really believe we have overhang of both these stocks based on an anticipated offering at DM. We also -- I think, as I mentioned earlier, people have been waiting for us to validate the structure of D and DM and those advantages and really answer the question, can you access the equity market at DM at a very high level that benefits both DM and D. So based on that, we elected to go early. We didn't have to do it until thethird quarter of next year, but we want to get it behind us. It does help us on financing a little bit at D next year, but the principal reason was to validate the model and to show the investor base that DM is a security that is sought-after. It has huge benefits to DM and D shareholders.

componenttext: The first question was you kind of indicated $7 billion to $8 billion of cash that you expect Dominion to generate from the MLP through 2020. headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Praful, this is Mark. I think you're going to see it in today's examples of a good one. You're going to see financing will be a combination of preferred, common units and debt by adding leverage at DM although as we said many times, we're going to make su
componenttext: Praful, this is Mark. I think you're going to see it in today's examples of a good one. You're going to see financing will be a combination of preferred, common units and debt by adding leverage at DM although as we said many times, we're going to make sure it's investment-grade rated when we decide to rate it. It's going to be a mix of the 3. We'll also potentially take back some units as part of that for tax planning purposes, but again with the ability today and the market we have today to raise over $1 billion for the first transaction out there and as the size of DM grows over the next couple of years, we're very optimistic about being able to put in place a financing. In terms of ownership, I think you could assume that for the next several years, our ownership is going to stay in the 50% range, and then over time toward the end of the decade, start to move down more into the 40% range.

headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you, and then originally you were talking about Millstone and just nuclear in general, you're talking about thinking about hedging depending on the support you get. Just want to get a little bit more color on what you expect in terms of the kind of su
componenttext: Got you, and then originally you were talking about Millstone and just nuclear in general, you're talking about thinking about hedging depending on the support you get. Just want to get a little bit more color on what you expect in terms of the kind of support. Is it similar to New York SEC kind of program or what you expect and where in the regulatory approval is that right now.

headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's go back to the hedging will happen, as Mark said, regardless of what the price is. We've done that for a long time. We will continue to do it into the future. So everybody knows what expectations we should have for earnings and cash flows. As far as
componenttext: Let's go back to the hedging will happen, as Mark said, regardless of what the price is. We've done that for a long time. We will continue to do it into the future. So everybody knows what expectations we should have for earnings and cash flows. As far as the New York example, as I understand New York is basically a taxpayer subsidization of 2 facilities in the northern part of New York without any support going to the Indian point reactors outside New York City. That's how I understand it. Just from reading the trade price, I see similar moves are being thought of in Illinois, for example. Connecticut has gone about it in a different way. They have an RPS standard there, and an auction has been established for some years where the LSEs bid, take their -- meet their RPS requirements by auctions from renewable suppliers into that RPS auction on an annual basis. The contemplation by the legislature, not the regulators in Connecticut is to expand that to a clean power standard that would include nuclear, which would allow up to approximately 50% of Millstone to be included in the auction. That, at this point, obviously is still in contemplation by the legislature. There is some momentum behind it. We're following it very closely. But it won't affect '17. It would affect '18 and beyond.

headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call for Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners.During this call, we will refer to certain schedules included in this morning's earnings releases and pages from our Ea
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call for Dominion Resources and Dominion Midstream Partners.
During this call, we will refer to certain schedules included in this morning's earnings releases and pages from our Earnings Release Kit. Schedules in the Earnings Release Kit are intended to answer the more detailed questions pertaining to operating statistics and accounting. Investor Relations will be available after the call for any clarification of these schedules. If you've not done so, I encourage you to visit the Investor Relations page on our websites, register for e-mail alerts and view our third quarter earnings documents. Our website addresses are dom.com and dommidstream.com.
In addition to the Earnings Release Kit, we have included a slide presentation on our website that will follow this morning's discussion.
And now for the usual cautionary language. The earnings releases and other matters that will be discussed on the call today may contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. Please refer to our SEC filings, including our most recent annual reports on Form 10-K and our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q for a discussion of factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecast, estimates and expectations.
Also on this call, we will discuss some measures of our company's performance that differ from those recognized by GAAP. Reconciliation of our non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures we are able to calculate and report are contained in the Earnings Release Kit and Dominion Midstream's press release.
Joining us on the call this afternoon are our CEO, Tom Farrell; our CFO, Mark McGettrick; and other members of our management team. Mark will discuss our earnings results for the third quarter and Dominion's earnings guidance for the fourth quarter. He will also discuss Dominion Midstream's financing of its planned acquisition of Questar Pipeline, which was priced this morning. Tom will review our operating and regulatory activities and review the progress we have made on our growth plans.
I will now turn the call over to Mark McGettrick.

headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Dominion Resources reported operating earnings of $1.14 per share for the third quarter of 2016, finishing well above the top of our guidance range. Positive factors relative to guidance for the quarter were favorable weather, lower operat
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Dominion Resources reported operating earnings of $1.14 per share for the third quarter of 2016, finishing well above the top of our guidance range. Positive factors relative to guidance for the quarter were favorable weather, lower operating expenses, an earlier approval of our Questar acquisition and partnership income from one of our large solar projects. Some of the partnership income is timing related and will reverse in the fourth quarter.
Negative factors were an unplanned outage at Millstone and higher major storm restoration costs.
GAAP earnings were $1.10 per share for the third quarter. The principal difference between GAAP and operating earnings were charges related to transaction costs for our merger with Questar. A reconciliation of operating earnings to reported earnings can be found on Schedule 2 of the Earnings Release Kit.
Moving to results by operating segment. At Dominion Virginia Power, EBITDA for the third quarter was $423 million, which was in the upper half of its guidance range. Favorable weather conditions were partially offset by higher major storm restoration costs. Dominion Generation produced EBITDA of $921 million in the third quarter, which exceeded the top of its guidance range. Favorable weather was the principal factor in the strong performance, partially offset by an unplanned outage at Millstone.
Third quarter EBITDA for Dominion Energy was $310 million, which was above the top of its guidance range. Lower operating expenses and an earlier-than-planned contribution from Questar were the principal drivers of the strong results. Overall, we are very pleased with the performance of each of our operating segments.
For the third quarter of 2016, Dominion Midstream Partners produced adjusted EBITDA of $27.9 million, 37% higher than the level produced in the third quarter of last year. Distributable cash flow increased 22% to $24.1 million, which was consistent with management's expectations.
On October 21, Dominion Midstream's Board of Directors declared a distribution of $0.2475 per unit payable on November 15. This distribution represents a 5% increase over last quarter's payment and is consistent with our plan to achieve 22% annual distribution growth for LP units.
Moving to cash flow and treasury activities at Dominion. Funds from operations were $3.1 billion for the first 9 months of the year. We have $5.5 billion of credit facilities, and taking into account cash, short-term investments and commercial paper outstanding, we ended the quarter with available liquidity of $2.5 billion.
For statements of cash flow and liquidity, please see Pages 14 and 25 of the Earnings Release Kit.
During the third quarter, we completed a number of financing transactions to support our growth plan and cover the acquisition of Questar. Slide 6 highlights our recent financing activities. We have one public debt financing plan for the remainder of this year at dev co.
Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, Dominion's operating earnings guidance is $0.90 to $1.05 per share. The midpoint of that range is $0.28 per share above operating earnings of $0.70 per share for the fourth quarter of 2015. Positive earnings drivers for the quarter compared to last year are return to normal weather, the absence of refueling outage at Millstone, lower capacity expenses and the addition of Questar. Negative drivers for the quarter compared to last year include higher financing costs and DD&A.
Dominion's operating earnings guidance for the year remains $3.60 to $4 per share.
As to hedging, you can find our hedge positions on Page 27 of the Earnings Release Kit. As of mid-October, we have hedged 8% of our expected 2017 production at Millstone. We expect to add to our hedges over the next 3 months and plan to have about 80% of our 2017 production hedged by the end of January.
So let me summarize my financial review. Operating earnings were $1.14 per share for the third quarter of 2016, which was well above our guidance range. Operating results for Dominion Midstream Partners were in line with management's expectations. And finally, Dominion's operating earnings guidance for the fourth quarter is $0.90 to $1.05 per share and full year earnings guidance remains $3.60 to $4 per share.
I will now turn the call over to Tom Farrell.

headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Strong operational and safety performance continued in the third quarter. All of our business units are on track to meet their safety goals for the year. We expect to set another company-wide safety record this year.Our nuclear fleet con
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Strong operational and safety performance continued in the third quarter. All of our business units are on track to meet their safety goals for the year. We expect to set another company-wide safety record this year.
Our nuclear fleet continues to operate well. The net capacity factor of our 6 units was 93% for the first 9 months of the year. The contribution of the Brunswick County Power Station helped our regulated power generation group achieve record net generation.
Now for an update on our growth plans. Construction of the 1,588 megawatt Greensville County combined cycle power station continues on time and on budget. Approximately 480 workers are on site performing civil and structural work. The $1.3 billion project is expected to achieve commercial operations in late 2018.
Our 2 large contracted solar projects, Four Brothers and Three Cedars in Utah, were completed in September on time and on budget. We own 50% of the 2 projects that have a combined capacity of 530 megawatts and are secured by 20-year power purchase agreements.
We have a number of solar projects under development in the state of Virginia and continue to see demand for renewables from our customers, including data centers, military installations and the state government. The 80-megawatt solar facility under Virginia's Eastern Shore is complete and went into service over this past weekend. 3 other Virginia solar projects totaling 56 megawatts are also expected to be in service by year-end.
Earlier this month, we announced a 60-megawatt solar development in North Carolina, secured by 25-year power purchase agreements. This project should also be in service by the end of this year.
We have filed with State Corporation Commission for approval of an additional 20-megawatt solar facility at the sight of our Remington Power Station to be in service next year. In July, we signed a lease with the Department of the Navy to develop an 18-megawatt solar facility at the Oceana Naval Air Station in Virginia. If approved by the State Corporation Commission, this solar facility is expected to be in service by late next year. This will bring our operating solar fleet to 1,200 megawatts by the end of 2017.
We are in discussions with multiple parties for further solar development in the future, and we fully expect to exceed our goal of adding 500 megawatts of solar farms in Virginia and North Carolina. We have a number of electric transmission projects at various stages of regulatory approval and construction. $580 million worth of these facilities have been completed so far this year, including our new systems operations center.
We expect to place over $730 million of new transmission assets into service by year-end.
Progress on our growth plan for Dominion Energy continues as well. Our Cove Point Liquefaction project is now 75% complete with over 2,000 construction workers on site. Our engineering, procurement and construction contractor, IHI Kiewit, has installed well over half of the 21,500 tons of the structural steel required, and the piping installation is proceeding on plan.
All major components have been delivered to the site, and all will be installed under foundations by year-end. Our operations staffing plan is also on schedule. The project continues to be on time and on budget for a late 2017 in-service date.
We're continuing to work toward the commencement of construction on the Atlantic Coast Pipeline and the related Supply Header project. FERC issued its notice of schedule on August 12. We expect to receive the draft EIS in a few weeks and the final EIS in June. We anticipate beginning construction upon receipt of the first certificate during the second half of next year. Surveying and pipeline engineering is nearly complete and will be finished this year. We're finalizing our detailed construction plans and on September 16, executed the construction contract with Spring Ridge Constructors. We expect completion of the Atlantic Coast Pipeline and Supply Header in the second half of 2019.
In addition to the Atlantic Coast Pipeline and Supply Header, we have 10 pipeline growth projects underway with $1 billion of investment to move 1.5 million cubic feet per day per customers by the end of 2018. Our Monroe to Cornwell project, with more than 200,000 dekatherms per day of capacity, was put into service in October, and we have another 3 projects to come online this year. Our new expansion projects are primarily demand driven, moving gas to end-use power generators for local distribution companies.
In regulatory matters, hearings were held earlier this month for Dominion's base rate case for our North Carolina service territories, seeking approval of a $51.1 million increase in base rate revenues. A settlement was reached with the staff and a group of industrial customers calling for a $34.7 million increase based on a 9.9% return on equity. We will implement the proposed rates subject to refund tomorrow with permanent rates becoming effective January 1 of next year. A decision is expected in December. 
Finally, I want to update you on our merger with Questar Corporation. The Public Service Commission of Utah approved the merger on August 23, and the Wyoming Public Service Commission approved it on September 14. We completed the merger 2 days later. Ron Jibson, Questar's retired Chairman and CEO, has joined Dominion's Board of Directors. Harry Simmons, the former Lead Director for Questar, has joined the board of Dominion Midstream Partners. We are excited about adding Questar to Dominion's operations and look forward to developing new growth opportunities in the Western states.
So to summarize, our business has delivered strong operating and safety performance in the third quarter. Construction of the Greensville County project is on time and on budget. Construction of the Cove Point Liquefaction project is on time and on budget. We continue to work toward FERC approval for the Atlantic Coast Pipeline and the Supply Header project, and we are excited about our future opportunities that will come as a result of our merger with Questar.
I will now return the call to Mark for a discussion of our financings at Dominion Midstream Partners.

headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom. We issued press releases this morning announcing the launch and subsequent pricing of Dominion Midstream financing to acquire Questar Pipeline.I wanted to discuss it on this afternoon's call for a number of reasons. First, it represents
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. We issued press releases this morning announcing the launch and subsequent pricing of Dominion Midstream financing to acquire Questar Pipeline.
I wanted to discuss it on this afternoon's call for a number of reasons. First, it represents one of the largest financing transactions by a publicly traded MLP this year. Second, based on the low initial yield for the preferred equity and the modest discount to market for the common units, this financing was the least expensive for an MLP issuer this year. It provides clear evidence of the high level of interest by investors in DM equity. Third, despite being one of the largest offerings this year, demand for the common equity was significantly oversubscribed, leading us to upsize the offering. Fourth, this successful financing validates our strategic plan for Dominion Midstream Partners, which involves accessing capital markets on advantageous terms to fund the acquisition of midstream assets of Dominion that will, in turn, support a 22% annual distribution growth rate. And finally, this successful financing and low achieved yields confirm the value-accretive proposition underlying the formation of Dominion Midstream 2 years ago for investors of both D and DM.
As noted in this morning's press releases, Dominion Midstream Partners will acquire 100% interest in Questar Pipeline on or about December 1 for an implied enterprise value of $1.725 billion or about 10.3x 2016 EBITDA. About $435 million of existing long-term debt will remain in place at Questar Pipeline, leaving net consideration of just about $1.3 billion.
As announced this morning, we have priced a common unit offering, including both an underwritten offering and a private placement, totaling some $500 million assuming underwriters exercise the greenshoe option. Again, I would note that this common unit offering registers as one of the largest MLP unit offerings of the year and at just 2.9% reflects by far the smallest discount to any trade of any offering this year.
We have also received commitments from a group of private investors, led by Stonepeak Infrastructure Partners, for up to $600 million in convertible preferred securities, which was priced together with this morning's offering and which closes in conjunction with the transaction at close on December 1. Among comparable securities offered by MLPs, this preferred security has the lowest-ever initial yield of 4.75% and an attractive conversion premium of 15%.
It is clear from the interest in DM preferred structure that investors see very high growth potential in DM shares. We very much appreciate the overwhelming interest and participation in this offering from both public and private investors.
At closing, the cash consideration to Dominion provided by these offerings will be used to repay existing Dominion level debt. We will also refinance the existing DM intercompany note with a 3-year term note from a group of banks.
As shown on Slide 19, including a $1.2 billion of proceeds from this transaction, we expect the MLP to generate about $7 billion to $8 billion in cash for Dominion through 2020, which we'll use to reduce holding company debt, increase dividends, invest in new growth projects and repurchase common stock.
We realize that D, DM structure is somewhat unique in the utility space, and investors have been waiting for us to begin to execute a drop-down strategy. We expect that with the success of today's transactions, both D and DM investors will see the clear long-term growth and value for both shareholders and unitholders.
With that, we'll be happy to take your questions.

componenttext: So perhaps, first, a quick question. Can you elaborate just a little bit on the Millstone hedging plan from here on out? I just to make sure if I heard you right. 80% from 8% largely today by early '17. Is that sort of irrespective of the commodity environment? And perhaps, more importantly, how are you thinking about hedging future years '18, '19 and to '20?

headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julien, this is Mark. The answer to the first part of your question is it's regardless of what the market power price will be between now and the end of January. We committed over many years to investors and the credit agencies that there will be a clear
componenttext: Julien, this is Mark. The answer to the first part of your question is it's regardless of what the market power price will be between now and the end of January. We committed over many years to investors and the credit agencies that there will be a clear firm cash flow stream from Millstone as we put guidance out in the current period. So we have always hedged Millstone in the 80-plus-percent range by the end of the year call, and we plan on doing the same for 2017. In terms of future periods, we will be very cautious on hedging Millstone for a number of reasons. One is we believe that the current forward strip is dramatically understating the value of the market; and second, as you know, there is a lot of discussion in Connecticut about potential legislation in the ability to Millstone bid into future auctions. We hope that would be cleared up in the first half of next year, and we would want to see what the outcome of that would be before we hedge 2018 and beyond.

headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016

componenttext: Got it. Excellent. And just to follow up real quickly, obviously, well done on closing Questar. What's the status in terms of future growth opportunity? headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julien, we -- the more we look, the more opportunities we see. The West -- that part of the West is largely powered by coal-fired power plants. Many of them are going to have to close or be converted to natural gas. There's an increasing amount of RPS req
componenttext: Julien, we -- the more we look, the more opportunities we see. The West -- that part of the West is largely powered by coal-fired power plants. Many of them are going to have to close or be converted to natural gas. There's an increasing amount of RPS requirements in states on -- particularly on the western seacoast where, as you know and I think investors know, the more renewables that are built, the more gas-fired peakers are going to be required to deal with the fact that it's intermittent. So that's just one potential opportunity that we see in the West. There's a lot of natural gas infrastructure that's going to be required in the future there. Now it's not on the same scale obviously as the Mid-Atlantic as far as population goes, but starting from the base that we have in the West, we think there's a tremendous amount of opportunity.

componenttext: Jeremy, this is Mark. We were very pleased -- although we were always confident as we stated to investors over the past many months based on what we've heard from investors, the lack of liquidity in the DM stock, we knew there will be a lot of interest. We've been particularly pleased with the convert and interest shown in that by multiple parties and the very aggressive financing around that. So I think that just reinforces our view that if we see an asset out there that fits the DM profile that we can fund it within the DM umbrella if we need to or with the parent support if required, but I think today's results just validate for us that the DM shares are highly valued and will be a great source of future equity and financing if we decide to enter the M&A stage at all.

componenttextpreview: Yes, our targets will be unchanged. And I think your reference is that the IRS after this calendar year do not allow certain tax shields that existed prior to that MLPs could make themselves available to, but we have a long-term tax planning for each of t
componenttext: Yes, our targets will be unchanged. And I think your reference is that the IRS after this calendar year do not allow certain tax shields that existed prior to that MLPs could make themselves available to, but we have a long-term tax planning for each of the years through 2020. We were aware of that potential down the road, and it will not impact either our growth rate or our distribution focus going forward. That has been incorporated into our tax planning for quite some time.

componenttext: Sure, Steve. This solar involves partnership income from one project, Four Brothers in Utah, and it's complicated partnership accounting. When we put the guidance out -- and actually we put the budget together this year, we thought the contribution would be evenly distributed over a number of quarters, but the final accounting determination required us to book $0.04 in the third quarter, and that will roll off $0.02 in the fourth quarter and $0.02 in the first half of next year. So that's a timing issue for the quarter, but for year-end, there is no impact on our guidance at all.

componenttext: Okay. And now the drop-down today to DM, clearly very successful, but is this coming a bit early? In a sense, I understand that the funds the you're raising for DM are aimed to delever the balance sheet, but are you in a sense trying to manage your interest expense for 2017 by accelerating the DM drop-down? Or is it simply an opportunistic timing?

headline: Dominion Midstream Partners, LP, Dominion Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's more of the latter. We really believe we have overhang of both these stocks based on an anticipated offering at DM. We also -- I think, as I mentioned earlier, people have been waiting for us to validate the structure of D and DM and those advantages
componenttext: It's more of the latter. We really believe we have overhang of both these stocks based on an anticipated offering at DM. We also -- I think, as I mentioned earlier, people have been waiting for us to validate the structure of D and DM and those advantages and really answer the question, can you access the equity market at DM at a very high level that benefits both DM and D. So based on that, we elected to go early. We didn't have to do it until the third quarter of next year, but we want to get it behind us. It does help us on financing a little bit at D next year, but the principal reason was to validate the model and to show the investor base that DM is a security that is sought-after. It has huge benefits to DM and D shareholders.
